event_title: Artist Talk: “Vessels of Devotion” by taylor barnes
event_summary: Join us for an artist talk with taylor barnes, a contemporary fibers artist and ceramicist whose work consists primarily of mixed media fibers techniques and charcoal on cloth.
event_description: Heart from the artist and enjoy light refreshments. barnes’ exhibition, “Vessels of Devotion,” will be on display in the J. Wayne Stark Galleries Sept. 25–Dec. 13, 2025.barnes’ work takes on subjects of spirituality, oral histories, power, and bell hooks philosophies testing the object/subject divide. Her figures are to be understood as her spiritual guides unbound by time. Her objects contain undeniable presences as activation of the inanimate is at the core of her practice. All this, guiding her to construct spaces in which their truths are revealed.
event_category: academic calendar, arts entertainment, campus life, general interest, international students, faculty, researcher, residents, staff, students, visitors, youth (k-12), bryan-college station

event_title: Eyewitness to Conflict: Prints Commemorating the 80th Anniversary of the End of WWII
event_summary: Marking the 80thanniversary of the end of World War II, this exhibition features WWII prints from the Sheryl and John L. Fiegel ’65 Collection. It brings together powerful works that reflect the vital role artists played in shaping the public consciousness of war and memory.
event_description: Exhibition on Display: July 31–Aug. 25, 2025Summer Hours | May 13–Aug. 25, 2025Tues.–Fri. 9 a.m.–5:30 p.m.; Sat. Noon–6 p.m; Closed Sun.–Mon.Regular Hours | Beginning Aug. 26, 2025Tues.–Fri. 9 a.m.–8 p.m.; Sat.–Sun. Noon–6 p.m; Closed Mon.Comprised of lithographs, woodcuts and etchings, this exhibition brings together powerful works that reflect the vital role artists played—and continue to play—in shaping the public consciousness of war and memory. These prints serve as both documentary records and poetic interpretations, capturing not only the devastation and resilience of people and places but also the emotional landscape of a world transformed by conflict.Drawing on Francis Brennan’s 1942 call that the American people needed their artists “to charge them with the grave responsibility of spelling out their anger, their grief, their greatness and their justice,” the exhibition honors those who responded through the enduring medium of printmaking—bearing witness, telling stories that history books cannot and offering deeply personal visions of collective experience.
event_category: academic calendar, arts entertainment, campus life, general interest, international students, faculty, researcher, residents, staff, students, visitors, youth (k-12), bryan-college station

event_summary: This exhibition celebrates the enduring legacy of the 1989 Runyon Family donation of 19thand 20thcentury art and decorative art and other complementary donations from private collectors.
event_description: Exhibition on Display: Sept. 9–Dec. 14, 2025Tues.–Fri. 9 a.m.–8 p.m.; Sat.–Sun. Noon–6 p.m.Since 1989 when the Runyon family donated a fantastic collection of 19thand 20thcentury art and decorative art, the Forsyth Galleries has set about amassing a fantastic collection that we enjoy sharing with the community. Those who love and appreciate the collection have, in turn, donated or loaned a significant number of items including paperweights, Asian art, early American pewter, American Brilliant Cut Crystal, 19thcentury quilts, small furniture items, as well as additional paintings, works on paper and art glass. This exhibition celebrates their generosity and, we hope, will inspire others to share their treasures with the University. THANK YOU!To inquire about donating works of late 19thand early 20thart or to make a contribution to the Forsyth Galleries, contact Assistant Director and Curator Elizabeth Appleby ateappleby@tamu.edu.
event_category: academic calendar, arts entertainment, campus life, deadlines, general interest, international students, faculty, researcher, residents, staff, students, visitors, youth (k-12), bryan-college station

event_summary: Silver Taps is that final tribute paid to an Aggie who, at the time of their death, was enrolled in professional, graduate or undergraduate courses at Texas A&M.View this month’s honorees
event_description: The ceremony begins on the day of Silver Taps when the flag in front of the Academic Building is placed at half-staff. Notices are posted at the Memorial Student Center, Evans Library, and at the base of the flagpole in front of the Academic Building. At 10:15 p.m., chimes from the Albritton Bell Tower begin to play. The ceremony begins at 10:30 p.m. as the Ross Volunteers Firing Squad marches in slow cadence to the statue of Lawrence Sullivan Ross. Three volleys are fired. “Silver Taps” is played by six buglers three times – to the North, West, and South. This concludes the ceremony, but not the feelings of respect and honor.With respect, the ceremony of Silver Taps is dedicated to the deceased Aggie and is a solemn and serious event. Some important observances must be remembered:The area in front of the Sul Ross statue and the Academic Building is reserved for the friends and family of the deceased.Aggies do not stand or sit on the benches lining the walkway between the flagpole and the Sul Ross Statue.The darkness and quiet, which cover the campus, emphasize the mood for Silver Taps. Aggies help to retain this tranquility by covering windows, keeping noise to a minimum, and walking to and from the ceremony without talking.The name of the deceased Aggie is posted on the flagpole base during the day of Silver Taps.
event_category: campus life, general interest, faculty, staff, students, visitors, bryan-college station

event_title: OPAS presents Soweto Gospel Choir - Peace
event_summary: OPAS presentsSoweto Gospel Choir - Peacein Rudder Auditorium on October 21 (7:30 PM).  Tickets available atMSC Box Office.
event_description: With their concert entitled “PEACE,” the multi-Grammy® and Emmy Award®-winningSOWETO GOSPEL CHOIRreturns to North America to perform a joyful program of South African freedom songs, traditional spirituals and some classics. The inspirational concert will also feature the spirited music of Aretha Franklin, Harry Belafonte, Leonard Cohen and more! Formed in 2002, the Choir was created to celebrate the unique power of African gospel music and quickly established itself as a group that is “undeniably synchronized, appears unshakable, and simultaneously expresses universality and individuality” (San Francisco Classical Voice). Heralded by Nelson Mandela, Desmond Tutu, and Oprah Winfrey,SOWETO GOSPEL CHOIRexcites audiences worldwide, uplifting the soul and spreading joy through its earthy rhythms, rich harmonies, brilliant costumes, and infectious spirit. It’s perfect for the entire family!VisitSoweto Gospel Choir - Peacefor more information about this program. Order tickets now at the Box Office. To see all of the shows coming to OPAS Season 53, visit our fullschedule page.

event_summary: Howdy Postdocs!The opportunity for Aggie postdocs to apply for travel funding generously provided by the Texas A&M Division of Research is now open. These awards support registration fees for virtual conferences and travel to in-person conferences!This travel funding applies to conferences occurring from January 1, through June 30, 2026.The deadline for this application period is October 17, 2025.CURRENT eligibility criteriaSpring 2026competition (travel Jan 1 - June 30, 2026):Must have a postdoctoral appointment at Texas A&M at the time of the application AND the time of travel.Awards are limited to one award per person within 12 calendar months.The applicant must be the presenting author of the conference abstract.To apply for the Fall 2025 Travel Award Competition (travel awards forJuly 1 - December 31, 2025) applicantsmust have attended at least two events organized by the Texas A&M Office of Postdoctoral Affairs and/or Texas A&M Postdoctoral Association during Summer/Fall 2024.First-semester postdocs are ineligible to apply.Application link and more details regarding application materials are posted at:u.tamu.edu/OPA_TravelAwardsIf you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contactseyre@tamu.eduOffice of Postdoctoral Affairs

event_title: George H.W. Bush’s Vision for Trade Across the Americas
event_summary: 5:00 p.m. Reception5:30 p.m. ProgramAnnenberg Presidential Conference Center1002 George Bush Drive WestThe Mosbacher Institute invites you to the2025 ConocoPhillips White House LecturefeaturingAmbassador John D. Negroponte, who will speak about President George H.W. Bush’s vision for free trade across the Americas and establishment of the North American Free Trade Act (NAFTA).RSVPThis event is highly relevant today as debates over free trade, regional integration, and global competition continue to shape U.S. economic policy. Ambassador (ret.) John Negroponte’s reflections on President George H.W. Bush’s vision for the North American Free Trade Agreement provide valuable historical context for current discussions about supply chains, economic resilience, and international partnerships. For Texas A&M students, the talk offers an opportunity to connect theory with practice, learn from a distinguished diplomat, and better understand how trade policy influences both global dynamics and local economic opportunities in Texas.Negroponte has served as Ambassador to Honduras, Mexico, the Philippines, the United Nations, and Iraq. He served twice on the National Security Council staff, first as Director for Vietnam in the Nixon Administration and then as Deputy National Security Advisor under President Reagan. He has also held a cabinet level position as the first Director of National Intelligence under President George W. Bush. His most recent position in government was as Deputy Secretary of State, where he served as the State Department’s Chief Operating Officer.The ConocoPhillips White House Lecture Series is sponsored by ConocoPhillips of Houston, Texas, whose 2002 endowment to the George and Barbara Bush Foundation established the program. The Lecture Series brings to public attention the various offices of the White House and Executive Branch that provide policy, administrative, and overall support to the President. The purpose is to bring to life the workings of the White House, a better understanding of the governmental process, and an opportunity to examine and understand the particular function and challenges of each office. In this manner, the series provides a more comprehensive picture of the Presidency and the people around the President.
event_category: speakers, forums, and conferences, faculty, researcher, residents, staff, students, visitors, youth (k-12), bryan-college station

event_summary: Join CGS and Nicholas Anderson from The George Washington University on 10/17 as he presents his research “Quagmire: Explaining Costly Military Intervention, 1918-2024”. Event is on Zoom.
event_description: Nicholas Anderson (Ph.D., Yale University) is an Assistant Professor of Political Science and International Affairs at The George Washington University. His research interests include great power politics, military intervention and territorial expansion, conventional military operations, and East Asian international relations. All are welcome to attend.

event_summary: Join CGS and Ionut Popescu of Texas State as he presents his research “No Peer Rivals: American Grand Strategy in the Era of Great Power Competition”. Event starts at 5:00 pm at the Annenberg Presidential Conference Center (APCC) on Wednesday, October 22nd.

Popescu will talk to CGS on his research pertaining to American grand strategy amidst a time of formidable great power competition.

event_title: TREC Single Cell Data Science Facility Core: A Two-Year Update
event_summary: “Advancing Cancer Research Through Single-Cell Data Science: Two Years of Progress and the Road Ahead”.A seminar-style update on the purpose, progress, and future plans for the Texas A&M Regional Center of Excellence in Cancer (TREC) Single Cell Data Science (SCDS) Facility Core. The seminar will be hosted in-person at theTexas A&M Medical Research Education Building, Room #1403,at the Texas A&M Health Science Center.Enjoy the opportunity to learn about the fascinating novel statistical methods to address the challenges in:Identifying cell types and their subsets,Characterizing cellular dynamics,Elucidating cell-cell communication and gene regulation at the single-cell level,Monitoring structural, functional, or phenotypic changes under different experimental conditions,Relating rare transitional cells or cell phenotypes to disease progression,Analysis of spatial transcriptomics, and,Integration of multi-omics single-cell data.In-person attendance of this seminar is preferred as this facilitates high-quality discussion, but remote attendance is available via Zoom.The Texas A&M Regional Center of Excellence in Cancer is proudly supported by the Cancer Prevention and Research Institute of Texas (RP230204).

event_title: The CIRTL Network Presents: Preparing a Teaching Demo for a Job Interview
event_summary: As part of the interview process for a faculty position, you may be asked to lead a teaching demonstration. In this interactive workshop, we’ll discuss ways to go into your teaching demo with preparedness, confidence, and adaptability. Participants will explore considerations related to their audience, factors affecting content, logistics (including technology), and teaching/learning interactions. Participants will also strategize ways to cope with unexpected challenges that could emerge during a teaching demo. By the end of this workshop, participants will be prepared to:Identify questions and decision points useful in preparing a teaching demo for a job interview.Strategize ways to gather the information needed to effectively plan a teaching demo.Generate strategies for dealing effectively with challenging situations that might emerge during a demo (e.g., logistical, technological, or interpersonal).

event_title: The CIRTL Network Presents: Writing an Effective Teaching Philosophy Statement
event_summary: Learn what a teaching philosophy statement is and how they are used in the academic job hunt, and explore your own teaching philosophy in a writing group of peers in this interactive, two-part online workshop. We will discuss elements of teaching statements, evidence of effective teaching tailored for different academic jobs, and strategies to get started or polish existing teaching statements. Participants from all disciplines will become better equipped and prepared to communicate their teaching practice through this workshop’s small group writing and feedback process. By the end of this workshop, participants will be able to:Understand common components of a teaching philosophy statementIdentify their own teaching accomplishments, beliefs, and goalsDraft a teaching philosophy statementRefine their work through peer review feedback

event_title: CIRTL: Introduction to Evidence- Based Undergraduate Teaching Course (October 8th-November 19th)
event_summary: This session meets weekly on Wednesdays at 3 PM starting on October 8th and ending on November 19th.CIRTL@Texas A&M facilitates at least one local learning community (LLC) a year on campus or via Zoom in conjunction with the online course. Each week participants will review the online materials and videos before coming together for face-to-face discussion on that week’s topic.The online courses are designed to provide current and future faculty, graduate students and post-doctoral fellows with an introduction to effective teaching strategies and the research that supports them, as well as the opportunity to discuss and share teaching resources.The goal of these seven-week courses is to equip the next generation of faculty to be effective teachers, thus improving the learning experience for the thousands of students they will teach.The courses draw on the expertise of experienced faculty, educational researchers, and staff from university teaching centers, many of them affiliated with CIRTL.

event_title: The CIRTL Network Presents: Shared Voices, Shared Decisions: Sociocracy for Educators and Leaders in Higher Ed
event_summary: University structure/governance varies little across the world and has changed little in basic form across time. It is, at its essence, deeply colonial and Western, characterized by a hierarchical distribution of power. However, as the world changes rapidly around us, there is a growing need to authentically include the diverse voices of stakeholders (i.e., staff and students) in the decisions that affect their work, learning, and wellbeing. This course presents a shared governance model, “Sociocracy”, that stresses inclusion and deliberate attention to power dynamics. Based on consent and not consensus, sociocracy operates at scales from small groups to entire organizations. Participants will explore connections among governance/decision-making, power structures, and participatory equity in higher education. They will explore sociocracy as a model for fostering shared decision-making in classrooms, committees, departments, and other academic spaces, and generate actionable plans to improve power dynamics and advance equity and inclusion in their own contexts. By the end of this course, participants will be able to:Identify relationships, power structures, and/or gaps in participatory equity in governance at their home institution.Define, explain, and justify the use of Sociocracy as a viable governance model at multiple levels or scales.Explain the significance of sociocratic structures and processes.Design sociocratic structures at levels or scales relevant to their local contexts.The course will also prepare participants to apply practical strategies that foster more equitable, inclusive, and participatory forms of leadership. These approaches are adaptable to a wide range of settings and contexts. Participants will learn how to:Structure and facilitate meetings effectively.Engage students as active partners in course design and learning.Incorporate regular feedback loops to improve processes, strengthen decision-making, and enhance collaborative projects.

event_title: The CIRTL Network Presents: Scaffolding Students’ Success as Independent Learners: Developing Instructional Materials Using Self-Regulated Learning Principles
event_summary: Gain practical skills to scaffold students’ development as independent learners using principles from self-regulated learning. This framework is goal-directed, and emphasizes the active role students can take in guiding their learning. Students’ implementation of these skills has been linked to many adaptive and positive academic outcomes. In this workshop, participants will explore practical methods to embed the teaching of self-regulated learning skills into their regular instruction, and learn how to feel more confident in their ability to design instructional materials that can help students take the initiative to plan, direct, and reflect on their own learning processes. By the end of this workshop, participants will be able to:Articulate the value of self-regulated learning processes (i.e., planning, monitoring/control, and reflection) in promoting student successDesign instructional materials to support students in developing disciplinary-based self-regulated learning skills

event_title: The CIRTL Network Presents: Fostering a Growth Mindset and Developing a Sense of Belonging in Your Students
event_summary: Learn from social and educational psychology in this one-part workshop on how instructors can foster growth mindsets in their students, and how that in turn can foster greater student motivation, achievement, and belonging. What factors hold back or push students forward in learning and performing the best they can? How do students react to successes and challenges? By the end of this workshop, participants will be prepared to:Understand the differences and relationship between growth mindset and sense of belongingConsider how students’ and instructors’ mindsets can impact student achievement and motivationIdentify concrete strategies to foster a growth mindset and sense of belonging in students

event_description: The Development of Sentences: A partnership between researchers and teachers to build an effective, sentence-writing curriculumAbstract: Sentences is a recently developed, Tier 1 curriculum for first grade that strengthened student sentence writing in an initial efficacy trial. event_summary: This is an in-person event, offering our fellows an opportunity to discuss their research with colleagues from different disciplines. However, the Glasscock Center is committed to providing access, when possible, to members of our community who are unable to attend in person for medical or other access reasons. event_description: Presenters:Sarah McNamara, Professor | History“Swing: A History of Florida’s Latino Vote”Pujarinee Mitra, Ph.D. Student | English“The Anti-Fascist Grandparents of India”Abstracts:McNamaraSwing: A History of Florida’s Latino Voteemerged from questions I am most frequently asked by scholars, students, and journalists when presenting my research: “Can you explain the Latino vote in Florida? Why does Florida swing during presidential elections?” Contrary to popular assumptions about Florida voting patterns, Florida’s Latino vote is not determined by a monolithic voting-bloc. Rather, multiple generations of immigrants from across the Caribbean and the Americas— all of whom have conflicting politics, migration motivations, and concepts of self— shape, and have long shaped, election outcomes in the state. As Florida becomes a testing ground for national policies, understanding the history that created the state becomes increasingly essential. In this presentation, I will introduce her project as well as community engaged work that amplifies connections between scholarship and public application of research.MitraIn 2020,Timemagazine named Bilkis Bano, an octogenarian protestor from Delhi, among the 100 most influential people in the world, referring to her as “the dadi from Shaheen Bagh.” The Shaheen Bagh movement (2019–2020) became a landmark in Indian anti-fascist resistance, as elderly Muslim women led mass protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens (NRC), which sought to disenfranchise undocumented minorities. This paper examines Bilkis’ 2020 interview onNews 18 Urdu, highlighting how the affectionate and intimate figure of thedadi(grandmother) reconfigures assumptions about political agency, gender, and age. I argue that the centrality of elderly Muslim women in Shaheen Bagh illuminates the affective politics of belonging, citizenship, and intergenerational resistance in contemporary India.Chair: Rick Pulos | Communication & JournalismPlease note that this is not a lecture, and thus, is not suited for class attendance. The Colloquium Series is intended to provide the presenter with a forum to discuss their research and receive feedback from colleagues and peers.

About the Aggie Lyceum: The Aggie Lyceum is a non-profit, non-partisan civil discourse, media literacy, and citizen engagement program that takes its name and inspiration from the Texas Lyceum and practices “civic friendship.”1:00-2:00Mapping Public Controversy, Dr. Mark HlavacikEffective leaders do not merely respond to controversies; they use effective communication to shape our understanding of them. In this interactive session you will learn how to recognize different types of controversy, analyze the key decision points in any controversy, and how to assess a leader’s options for how to respond to them.2:00-3:00Diagraming Arguments for Easy Analysis, Dr. Jen MerciecaIn a world awash in persuasion it’s difficult to know how to begin to analyze the evidence, reasoning, and claims that form an argument. In this interactive session you will learn a model of analysis that allows us to break down any argument into its individual parts so that you can easily assess and evaluate it.3:00-4:00How to Read Like a Lawyer, Dr. David KoepsellLearn to approach texts with the precision and insight of a lawyer. This interactive session introduces you to strategies for reading cases, statutes, and arguments critically and effectively, helping you to break down complex language, identify key issues, and sharpen your analytical skills. Whether you’re preparing for law school or simply want to strengthen your critical reading abilities, this session will equip you with practical tools you can use in any field.4:00-5:00Thinking Like a News Editor, Professor Mariano CastilloHow much do you trust the news media? In this interactive session you will learn strategies for sizing up news reports across traditional and social media platforms. We’ll discuss some tough decisions that editors must make about sensitive and controversial stories. Students will get the chance to put themselves in the shoes of a news manager and discuss what decisions they would make under tough circumstances.Our Workshops will last about 45 minutes with about 20 minutes of each event devoted to learning a new citizenship skill and about 25 minutes devoted to practicing the new skill.Advance registration is required. Click the link on the title to register.

event_description: Presenters:Ilayda Onder, Assistant Professor | Political Science“Performative Rebel Governance and Legibility: Evidence from Southeast Turkey”Noah Crawford, Ph.D. Student | History“‘Humanity’s Cause’: The International Dimensions of the American Civil War Refugee Crisis”Abstracts:OnderRebel groups often engage in performative governance acts that mimic the symbolic repertoires of sovereign states (e.g., printing currency, holding funeral rites, or building mausoleums). How do these acts shape rebel-constituency ties? I conceptualize performative rebel governance as a legibility-oriented strategy for identifying loyal civilians in harder-to-reach communities—those beyond the rebels’ immediate networks. Yet, these same acts also increase the legibility of rebellion to the state, exposing pro-rebel civilians to surveillance and paradoxically trading off the ability to expand rebels’ mobilization base beyond their traditional networks for an overall decline in mobilization. I provide evidence for this theory using original spatial event data on the funeral rites of PKK fighters in Southeast Turkey with microdata on PKK recruitment. The findings show that while funeral rites increase the recruitment of women and individuals with no history of political activism or family ties to the rebel movement, overall recruitment declines. These results reveal an inherent dilemma in rebel governance in contested spaces: while governance helps insurgents overcome informational deficiencies by eliciting civilian agency to reveal allegiances, it simultaneously renders the social landscape of war more legible to the government side of the conflict.CrawfordAs Union and Confederate armies battled to the east, the Texas-Mexico border region along the Rio Grande became a hotspot for refugee activity as pro-Union Texans fled to Mexico—a fellow republican state—that had already abolished slavery. By 1863, northern Mexico was embroiled in a civil war of its own as imperial France tried to install a European-style state on Mexico. Unionists in Mexico were surprised to find solidarity with Liberal Republican Mexican forces and even joined forces to combat Confederate Texans and French soldiers alike. The principles of transnational republicanism drew the United States and the Republic of Mexico together during the 1860s and reinforced the principles of an abolitionist ballad that encouraged its listeners to heed “humanity’s call.” This paper contextualizes the American Civil War’s refugee crisis as part of a larger nineteenth century Atlantic world that blended liberation ideology with republican principles.Chair: Seulgiye Kim | EnglishPlease note that this is not a lecture, and thus, is not suited for class attendance. The Colloquium Series is intended to provide the presenter with a forum to discuss their research and receive feedback from colleagues and peers.

event_title: Metaphysics of the Anthropocene. A Workshop on the Thought of Jean Vioulac
event_summary: Humanities and the AnthropoceneJean Vioulac (Béziers, France, 1971) is one of the great contemporary French thinkers. His work attempts an ontology of the present through a focus on technology, the Anthropocenic predicament, a critique of mathematization, and an emphasis on the need for an an-archeology of history premised on a genealogy of (broken) hegemonic principles. This workshop will discuss his philosophical project and benefit from his presence among us. It will include an open conversation with the audience.
event_description: Featured:Rafael Fernández López, Graduate Student in Hispanic Studies, Texas A&MStefano Franchi, Independent Scholar, Austin, TXDr. Humberto González Núñez, Assistant Professor of Philosophy, U of Texas-DallasAna Luisa Guimaraes, Graduate Student in Spanish, U of MichiganDr. Phil Lynes, Assistant Professor of Philosophy, U of Dundee, UKDr. Kurt Mertel, Associate Professor of Philosophy, American University of Sharja, UAEDr. Alberto Moreiras, Professor of Global Studies, Texas A&MDr. Matt Peterson, Postdoctoral Fellow in Religious Studies, U of Southern CaliforniaMartina Villalobos, Graduate Student in German, Cornell UniversityDr. Sergio Villalobos-Ruminott, Professor of Romance Languages, U of MichiganDr. Jean Vioulac, Professor of Philosophy, Lycée Auguste Blanquin, FranceDr. Gareth Williams, Professor of Romance Languages, U of MichiganDr. Krzysztof Ziarek, Professor of Comparative Literature, U of Buffalo \Sponsors: Humanities and the Anthropocene Initiative, Melbern G. Glasscock Center for Humanities Research, Texas A&M, Critical Theory Collective, Texas A&M

event_title: Hurston & the Law: Hoodoo, Barn Courts & Legalities of African American Folk
event_summary: Research on Zora N. Hurston’s engagement with Black Legal Culture in rural, colonial, and carceral spaces.
event_description: This gathering brings together a select group of scholars whose work engages Hurston’s understudied contributions to legal culture, race-making, and spatial justice in rural, carceral, and colonial contexts across the African Diaspora. Drawing on Hurston’s fiction, plays, folklore collections, journalism, and anthropological fieldwork between 1927 and 1953, this symposium will critically examine how African-descended communities understood, challenged, and navigated legal systems and law-adjacent themes beyond the reach of formal courts and civil rights jurisprudence.

event_description: Presenters:Stephen Riegg, Associate Professor | History“Imperial Hopes and Evangelical Disappointment: Scottish and Swiss Missions in Tsarist Russia’s Caucasus”Lauren Nyquist, Ph.D. Student | GeographyAbstracts:RieggThis paper is a draft of the “Introduction” to my in-progress book manuscript. The project addresses how Russian officials at the turn of the nineteenth century faced a colonial problem that they realized required innovation: the long-coveted Caucasus region could not be annexed through the traditional use of Cossack cavalry and Slavic settlers alone. For help, they turned to Western Europe. My book shows how and why tsarist officials “outsourced” certain tasks of empire building. Romanov imperialists improvised a trial-and-error program of tolerating the settlement of Scottish missionaries, French silk barons, German schismatics, and Swiss evangelicals in these strategically vital borderlands. With both alacrity and apprehension, the Russian state hoped to secure the sociopolitical stability and economic vitality of its Caucasus dominion through the collaboration of foreign expatriates.NyquistMore information forthcoming.Chair: Zachary Stewart | ArchitecturePlease note that this is not a lecture, and thus, is not suited for class attendance. The Colloquium Series is intended to provide the presenter with a forum to discuss their research and receive feedback from colleagues and peers.

event_title: Humanity at the Crossroads: AI, Genetic Engineering, and Chinese Science Fiction
event_summary: Asian Studies Working GroupDr. Ban Wang explores the provocative vision of acclaimed Chinese science fiction writer HaoJingfangin this compelling talk.Through Hao’s narratives, Dr. Wang investigates how artificial intelligence and genetic engineering are dramatically reshaping ourunderstanding of what it means to be human. Dr. Wang reveals a fascinating paradox: as technology blurs the boundariesbetween human and machine, it simultaneously obscures and illuminates our fundamental needs for emotional connection andmeaningful rituals around life’s most challenging moments.
event_description: Featuring:Dr. Ban Wang,William Haas Professor in Chinese Studies, Stanford UniversityPresented by the Asian Studies Working Group at the Glasscock Center.Additionalsupport provided by the Department of Global Languages & Cultures

event_title: National Arts and Humanities Month: Maroon Steel
event_summary: In celebration of National Arts and Humanities Month, the Glasscock Center is supporting pop-up presentations put on by student organizations.Maroon Steel will be performing during the 12:25pm to 12:45pm passing period at the LAAH/GLAS Breezeway.
event_description: According toAmericans for the Arts, “October is National Arts & Humanities Month (NAHM)—a collective recognition of the importance of culture in America. NAHM was launched by Americans for the Arts more than 30 years ago as National Arts Week in honor of the twentieth anniversary of the National Endowment for the Arts and National Endowment for the Humanities. In 1993, it was reestablished by Americans for the Arts and national arts partners as a month-long celebration, with goals of:FOCUSING on equitable access to the arts at local, state, and national levels;ENCOURAGING individuals, organizations, and diverse communities to participate in the arts;ALLOWING governments and businesses to show their support of the arts; andRAISING public awareness about the positive impact of the arts and humanities in our communities and lives.The arts are a national asset and should be available everywhere to everyone—and while a majority of the public believes this based on public opinion polling and other research, it’s often not their default way of thinking about the arts. National Arts & Humanities Month is an opportunity for everyone to help change public perception and promote the crucial role of the arts and humanities in promoting individual wellbeing, addressing trauma, connecting cultures, highlighting inequities, and making our communities healthier and stronger.”

event_title: CAREER: Introduction to the NSF CAREER Program with Recent Awardees Lunch
event_description: This Kick-off to the FY25 RDS CAREER Assistance Program begins with an introduction to the National Science Foundation’s Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program and includes an awardee panel lunch. Topics covered include PI eligibility, deadlines, proposal requirements, what makes the CAREER program different from other NSF programs, why CAREER proposals are not typical research proposals, how CAREER proposals are reviewed differently from typical research proposals, and available resources to assist faculty with preparing CAREER proposals.

event_title: National Arts and Humanities Month: Aggieland Mariachi
event_summary: In celebration of National Arts and Humanities Month, the Glasscock Center is supporting pop-up presentations put on by student organizations.Aggieland Mariachi will be performing during the 12:25pm to 12:45pm passing period at the LAAH/GLAS Breezeway.
event_description: According toAmericans for the Arts, “October is National Arts & Humanities Month (NAHM)—a collective recognition of the importance of culture in America. NAHM was launched by Americans for the Arts more than 30 years ago as National Arts Week in honor of the twentieth anniversary of the National Endowment for the Arts and National Endowment for the Humanities. In 1993, it was reestablished by Americans for the Arts and national arts partners as a month-long celebration, with goals of:FOCUSING on equitable access to the arts at local, state, and national levels;ENCOURAGING individuals, organizations, and diverse communities to participate in the arts;ALLOWING governments and businesses to show their support of the arts; andRAISING public awareness about the positive impact of the arts and humanities in our communities and lives.The arts are a national asset and should be available everywhere to everyone—and while a majority of the public believes this based on public opinion polling and other research, it’s often not their default way of thinking about the arts. National Arts & Humanities Month is an opportunity for everyone to help change public perception and promote the crucial role of the arts and humanities in promoting individual wellbeing, addressing trauma, connecting cultures, highlighting inequities, and making our communities healthier and stronger.”

event_title: Fall Speaker Series - Teacher Preparation Pathways: What Elements Matter and Who Makes It Through?
event_summary: 2 pm - 4 pm  Presentation followed by Questions & Answers.4 pm - 5 pm  Reception in Rudder 707Zoom Option Available - Click the Link AboveMeeting ID: 918 9739 1577Passcode: 970740
event_description: In this presentation, Dan Goldhaber will cover work on what we know about the influence of teacher preparation on teacher quality in the classroom. He will focus on (relatively) recent evidence about the degree to which there is variation in teacher effectiveness associated with where teachers received their credentials and the effectiveness of the teacher who served as the cooperating teacher during student achievement. And he will present new evidence on the factors predicting whether college students progress through the early teacher pipeline.Bio:Dr. Dan Goldhaber is the Director of the Center for Analysis of Longitudinal Data in Education Research (CALDER,caldercenter.org) at the American Institutes for Research and the Director of the Center for Education Data & Research (CEDR) at the University of Washington. Both CALDER and CEDR are focused on using state administrative data to do research that informs decisions about policy and practice.Dan’s work focuses on issues of educational productivity and reform at the K-12 level, the broad array of human capital policies that influence the composition, distribution, and quality of teachers in the workforce, and connections between students’ K-12 experiences and  post-secondary outcomes. Topics of published work in this area include studies of the stability of value-added measures of teachers, the effects of teacher qualifications and quality on student achievement, and the impact of teacher pay structure and licensure on the teacher labor market.

event_summary: Generative Al has entered our classrooms and conversations with remarkable speed —promising innovation, raising alarms, and sparking debates. event_description: In this thought-provoking session, Dr. Mishra will explore the paradoxes of GenAl in teaching and learning.Drawing on his deep expertise in educational technology, he will unpack both the possibilities and pitfalls of working with systems that dazzle with intelligence while stumbling in unexpected ways. Through stories, insights, and provocations, this talk will invite participants to reflect on their own roles as educators in an age where Al is no longer science fiction but part of our daily reality.

event_description: How to Compete:Step 1:Read through this page and understand the rules and processStep 2:Fill out the registration form.Step 3: Create your art.Step 4:Submit your art and information through this button.If you do not fill out this form, your art will not be judgedStep 5:Wait to hear the judging results. The top 10 art submissions will be contacted. If you would like to inquire about your scoring, please reach out toengr-ags@tamu.edu.Theme:“Engineering Elegance: The Art of Innovation”This theme invites participants to explore the hidden beauty within engineering processes, designs, and innovations. The idea is to highlight the harmony between form and function, showcasing how intricate structures, machines, and systems can be as visually striking as they are technically brilliant. Whether through sketches of complex mechanisms, digital renderings of futuristic architecture, or photography of elegant engineering solutions in nature and technology, the theme celebrates the artistic side of engineering ingenuity.Participants can draw inspiration from topics like:Symmetry and Precision: Emphasizing the mathematical beauty of designs, from gear systems to aerospace structures.Fluidity and Motion: Capturing the grace of engineered movements—robots, aerodynamics, or flowing liquids in fluid dynamics.Abstract Engineering: Focusing on conceptual designs, blueprints, or geometric patterns found in engineering drafts and CAD models.This theme encourages participants to blend creativity and engineering to reveal the elegance behind technical achievements.Canvas Pickup:If you would like to pick up afreecanvas, please visit ZACH 521!Submission Guidelines:Art submissions can be digital, image-based or canvas-based, and must follow the themeEngineering Elegance: The Art of Innovation. Submissions must include a title and a 400-500-character artwork description.Acceptable physical and digital art sizes:Minimum ppi =30011” x 14” = 3300 x 4200 pixels12” x 12” = 3600 x 3600 pixels12” x 16” = 3600 x 4800 pixels12” x 18” = 3600 x 5400 pixels16” x 16” = 4800 x 4800 pixels16” x 20” = 4800 x 6000 pixels16” x 24” = 4800 x 7200 pixels18” × 24” = 5400 x 7200 pixelsFile type: .jpg .png .pdf .epsNon-traditional art (3D, sculptures, etc.) can be submitted if the final art piece can be securely hung. Please contactengr-ags@tamu.edufor clarification.Elements that will not be considered:Trademarked University SymbolsRevellieUniversity SealsAltered University/College LogosAI ArtIf you are unsure about a symbol or design that you wish to include, please reach out toengr-ags@tamu.edufor clarification.The submission deadline for this event is October 10th at 5:00 p.m.Please submit physical art to ZACH 521. Once ready to submit, please fill out the form in the button below with information regarding your art submission. This formmustbe filled out for both physical and digital submissions.Selection Process:All entries will be judged out of 10 points in five categories for a total of 50 points possible. Please note that the title and art description will be considered with the art submission.The categories are as follows:Creativity and OriginalityRelevance to the ThemeTechnique and SkillEmotional ImpactConcept and StorytellingThe top 10 submissions will receive an exclusive custom prize.Submissions will be prominently displayed outside of the Dean’s Suite on the 5th floor of the Zachry Engineering Education Complex until the ’26-’27 Engineering Art Competition.FAQs:This section will be updated periodically as questions are asked.Who can participate?Any current Aggie Engineering student at any grade level (Freshman- PhD)Can I submit more than one art piece?We ask that you only submit one piece of art.What art mediums are allowed?You can utilize any art medium as long as the art can be hung.Can my art have 3D elements?As long as the elements are secured to the canvas any will Not be easily removed.

event_title: AERO Seminar: Computation of Hypersonic Flow and its Effects on Materials, Structures and Trajectories
event_summary: Dr. Iain BoydH.T. Sears Memorial Professor of Aerospace Engineering SciencesUniversity of Colorado
event_description: AbstractThe development of hypersonic vehicles is of broad international interest today for applications in national security, deep space exploration, and the emerging space economy. While the first hypersonic vehicle flew more than 70 years ago, their effective design still faces major technical challenges. The overarching cause of this difficulty stems from the fact that many key individual physical processes relevant to hypersonic flight are tightly coupled. Thegas dynamicsof the air flow around the vehicle creates temperatures of thousands of degrees leading to internal energy excitation and chemical reactions. The hot, oxidized gas in contact with the surfaces of the vehicle leads tomaterial responsephenomena such as conduction, radiation, and ablation. The thermally soaked material alters thestructural responseto the aerodynamic loading. Changes in the vehicle outer mold line due to ablation and structural deformation change the basic aerodynamic performance and thus affect theflight dynamics. With advanced numerical algorithms and modern computer architectures, it is becoming possible to include many of these complex processes in hypersonic vehicle analyses. This talk will review the current status for computational modeling of each separate discipline as well as efforts to couple these processes together. Key aspects for coupling include consideration of timescales associated with different processes and multi-fidelity simulation approaches.BIOIain D. Boyd is the H. T. Sears Memorial Professor of Aerospace Engineering Sciences at the University of Colorado – Boulder where he also serves as the Director of the Center for National Security Initiatives. He received a Ph. D. in aeronautics and astronautics (1989) from the University of Southampton in England. His research interests involve the development and application of physical models and computational methods for analysis of nonequilibrium gas and plasma dynamics processes in aerospace systems. He has authored over 250 journal articles, more than 400 conference papers, and published a book entitled “Nonequilibrium Gas Dynamics and Molecular Simulation.” Dr. Boyd is a Fellow of the American Institute for Aeronautics & Astronautics (AIAA), the American Physical Society, and the Royal Aeronautical Society. He has received the AIAA Lawrence Sperry Award and the AIAA Thermophysics Award. Dr. Boyd is the Director of a NASA-funded Space Technology Research Institute on hypersonic entry systems and leads a major Department of Defense project on hypersonic plasma formation.

event_title: ECE CESG Seminar: “Hardware is the New Software: The Next-Gen Anti-Viruses and How Your Hardware Will Self-Secure Your System!”
event_summary: Dr. Marcus BotacinComputer Science Assistant ProfessorTexas A&M University
event_description: Abstract:New threats require new defenses. In the same way that LLMs are reshaping malware creation, hardware support for security should be reshaping defenses. In this talk, Dr. Botacin presents the proposal for the migration of AV engines to hardware to implement continuous monitoring systems (Zero-Trust) with low performance impact. The presentation incrementally complexifies hardware design, from external FPGA AVs to the redesign of the memory controller. The talk discusses ideas like adding new Memory Management Unit (MMU) flags to create a new type of page fault – the security fault – to create security-aware OSes that invoke AntiViruses (AVs) on demand to scan processes in more suitable states. Dr. Botacin’s research talk will highlight how AVs can be significantly enhanced by relying on additional hardware support and will call for action to advance their development.BIO:Dr. Botacin is a Computer Science Assistant Professor at Texas A&M University (TAMU, USA) since 2022. Ph.D. in Computer Science (UFPR, Brazil), master’s in computer science and computer engineering (UNICAMP, Brazil). Malware Analyst since 2012. Specialist in AV engines and Sandbox Development. Dr. Botacin published research papers at major academic conferences and journals. Dr. Botacin also presented his work at major industry and hacking conferences, such as HackInTheBox and Hou.Sec.Con.
event_category: faculty, researcher, staff, students, bryan-college station

event_title: ECE Distinguished Speaker Seminar: “Resonance Phenomenon in Sensing – Only a Matter of Time”
event_summary: Srinivas TadigadapaProfessorDepartment of Electrical and Computer EngineeringNortheastern University
event_description: Abstract:The field of micro and nano sensors has rapidly evolved over the last couple of decades with many of the highest performance devices exploiting the phenomenon of resonance for sensing. Micro and nano scale designs, fabrication, and integration of new materials offer unique opportunities for innovative, novel, and robust sensor configurations. Examples of micromachined electromechanical, acoustic, optical, and nanoscale resonator devices will be presented. Resonator based sensors including temperature and infrared sensors, magnetic sensors, and chemical and biological sensors will be discussed. An overview of critical design considerations such as resonator geometry, the Q-factor, and performance advantages of these devices will be presented.BIO:Srinivas Tadigadapa is a Professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering at Northeastern University in Boston, USA where he has served as the chair of the department (2108 – 2023) and as Senior Vice Provost (2024 – 2025). From 2000 – 2017 he was a Professor of Electrical Engineering at the Pennsylvania State University. Dr. Tadigadapa’s primary research interest is in the interdisciplinary field of microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) and in the design, optimization, fabrication, and testing of MEMS transducers. Specifically, his research focus is on fabrication of novel micro and nano-sensors and actuators by integrating non-traditional materials using silicon microfabrication techniques and exploring phenomenon at the micro-nano interfaces. He has published over 200 peer reviewed papers in the field of MEMS and is the inventor on eleven patents. He was awarded the Alexander von Humboldt fellowship in Germany and the Walton fellowship by the Science Foundation of Ireland and is the recipient of the Meritorious Service Award from IEEE Sensors Council. He is a Fellow of the IEEE, The Institute of Physics, London, and a Life-Fellow of the Cambridge Philosophical Society. He was the founding editor of IEEE Sensors Letters.

event_title: ECE APT Faculty Candidate Seminar: “Positive Feedback Circuits: Making Use of Instability”
event_summary: Mohammad Mahdi GhahramaniPostdoctoral ResearcherTexas A&M University
event_description: Abstract:This seminar will begin with an undergraduate lecture on positive feedback op amps, showing how circuits that appear unstable can be analyzed and applied in practice. I will then share my teaching philosophy and vision, emphasizing active learning, hands-on experiences, and curriculum development that integrates emerging technologies and modern tools. My goal is to equip Aggies for successful and impactful careers in academia, industry, and beyond.Bio:Mohammad Mahdi Ghahramani was born in Shiraz, Iran. He earned the B.E. degree with First Class Honours in Microelectronics from University College Cork, Ireland, and the M.Sc. and Ph.D. degrees in Electrical Engineering from the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor. He is currently a postdoctoral researcher at Texas A&M University, working on high-speed data converters to meet the growing demand for data rates in cloud computing and AI. He previously spent over a decade in senior design roles at Qualcomm and AMD, leading innovations in RF, analog, and mixed-signal integrated circuits for wireless and server products deployed in millions of devices. He has authored several publications in top-tier conferences and journals, holds multiple patents, and was a finalist for the Best Student Paper Award at RFIC 2015. Throughout his career, he has built a strong track record of mentorship by guiding interns, junior engineers, and undergraduate and graduate students in both technical development and professional growth. He is passionate about teaching circuit theory, electronics, and emerging topics in analog/mixed-signal integrated circuit design, and he strives to inspire in students a lifelong curiosity for learning.Zoom option:https://tamu.zoom.us/j/93316119173
event_category: faculty, researcher, staff, students, bryan-college station

event_title: Smart Grid Center Short Course: Fundamentals of Electric Transmission System Planning Three-Day Short Course
event_summary: This short course is designed to provide a comprehensive coverage of the fundamentals of the planning of high voltage electric power systems.Register Now!
event_description: High voltage electric grids are some of the world’s most complex machines, whose present high levels of reliability have been achieved through careful planning. The purpose of this three day short course is to provide a comprehensive coverage of the processes used in doing this planning. The course philosophy is to provide a practical, hands-on approach to describing electric transmission grid planning, with abundant practical examples illustrating each stage in the process. Particular attention will be given to those studies driven by regulatory processes relevant to utilities in North America such as by the U.S. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) or the North American Electric Reliability Corporation (NERC). Throughout the course concepts will be illustrated using common industrial planning tools including PowerWorld Simulator with some hands-on exercises. Collectively the three course instructors have decades of experience in doing electric power system planning, planning software tool development, and engineering education (Hours: CEU 2.1, PDH 21).This course counts toward theTexas A&M Certificate in Electrical Power Engineering.

event_title: ECE CESG Seminar: “Learning the World in 3D: Real-Time Algorithms and Scalable Data”
event_summary: Dr. Zhiwen FanAsst. Professor, Dept. Electrical & Comp. EngineeringTexas A&M University
event_description: Abstract:3D foundation models are a key step toward spatial and physical intelligence, yet their impact is often constrained by heavy computation and scarce, well-curated 3D data. In this talk, I will present “a family of 3D algorithms that make reconstruction, rendering, and generation practical on real workloads, together with a scalable 3D data engine spanning human avatars, Martian-surface” simulation, and cryo-EM microscopy. First, I will cover: (1) city-scale 3D reconstruction and a real-time 3D perception Transformer that operates from uncalibrated images; (2) efficient neural rendering techniques that achieve 60% speedup over 3D Gaussian Splatting while preserving fidelity; and (3) methods by which explicit 3D understanding augments 2D vision–language models to improve spatial awareness prior to reasoning. Next, I will introduce systematic remedies for 3D data scarcity: (1) an automated pipeline for multimodal human-avatar and environment annotation; (2) a reliable system for simulating Martian surfaces under limited texture availability; and (3) a learned inverse Fourier-slicing map that enables cryo-EM reconstructions up to 10× faster without sacrificing accuracy. Taken together, these advances move us toward AI systems that interact with the physical world with genuine spatial understanding and real-time performance.BIO:Zhiwen (“Aaron”) Fan is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering at Texas A&M University. He received his Ph.D. from The University of Texas at Austin. He was awarded the 2022 Qualcomm Innovation Fellowship and a Best Paper award at the CVPR AI4CC Workshop. He has served as an Area Chair for multiple AI/ML conferences and has completed research internships at Meta, NVIDIA, and Google.
event_category: faculty, researcher, staff, students, bryan-college station

event_title: ECE Energy & Power Group Seminar: Improving Power Flow Convergence By Leveraging Region of Attraction Visualization
event_summary: Kseniia ZhgunPh.D. StudentElectrical & Computer EngineeringTexas A&M University
event_description: Abstract:Newton–Raphson (NR) power flow can readily converge to alternative, non-operational solutions. Using visualizations of the region of attraction (ROA), the paper demonstrates that the routine flat start (1 p.u., 0°) often lies outside the basin of the desired operating point, especially in large systems. Guided by these diagnostics, three computationally tractable approaches are evaluated: (i) rectangular-form NR with an optimal multiplier, (ii) voltage-dependent load switching from constant-power to constant-current/impedance below thresholds, and (iii) a lightweight pre-solve heuristic that adjusts initial voltages at buses implicated by extreme initial branch-flow mismatches. The results deliver a clear geometric understanding of NR behavior and practical applications that integrate with existing solvers.BIO:Kseniia is a 3rd-year PhD student in Electrical Engineering (Energy and Power Group) at Texas A&M University in Professor Overbye’s group. Her research focuses on enhancing power-flow convergence and improving power-system resilience. She earned her BS and MS from the Moscow Power Engineering Institute and previously worked in industry on power-system design, construction, and technical consulting.
event_category: faculty, researcher, staff, students, bryan-college station

event_summary: Speaker 1:Xiaoyang WangPh.D. StudentElectrical & Computer EngineeringTexas A&M University“Seamless Hybrid Multi-Mode Control of Grid-Forming and Grid-Following Inverters”Speaker 2:Bart SzymanowskiPh.D. StudentElectrical & Computer EngineeringTexas A&M University”Methodology and Convergence Considerations in an Integrated Transmission and Distribution System Power Flow”
event_description: Wang Abstract:As power systems become increasingly dominated by renewable resources interfaced through power electronic inverters, achieving stable and flexible grid synchronization is a critical challenge. Conventional Grid-Forming (GFM) and Grid-Following (GFL) inverters offer complementary capabilities, but are typically treated as separate paradigms, making seamless transitions between modes difficult. This talk presents a hybrid GFM–GFL control framework based on Virtual Oscillator Control (VOC), which integrates both power-synchronization and droop-synchronization mechanisms within the Andronov–Hopf nonlinear oscillator. The proposed approach enables multi-mode operation: the inverter can function as either Frequency-Forming or Frequency-Following, and as either Voltage-Forming or Voltage-Following. By adjusting the strength of grid feedback signals, smooth and continuous transitions trajectories between these operating modes are achieved. The effectiveness of the framework is demonstrated through simulations, highlighting seamless on-grid transitions and robust performance in islanded operation.Wang Biography:Xiaoyang Wang is a second-year PhD student in Electrical Engineering at Texas A&M University, working with Dr. Xin Chen in the Smart Power, Energy, and Decision-making (SPEED) Lab. He earned his Bachelor’s and Master’s degrees in Electrical Engineering from Xi’an Jiaotong University (XJTU). His research focuses on the modeling, parameter identification, and control of inverter-based resource (IBR)-rich power systems. He has been awarded the 2024–2025 ECE Graduate Merit Fellowship and the 2025–2026 Thomas Powell ’62 Fellowship.Szymanowski Abstract:The growing use of distributed generation, electric vehicles, demand response, and advanced metering infrastructure has increased the coupling between transmission and distribution networks. Because these systems are traditionally modeled under different assumptions, integrated analysis is both challenging and computationally demanding. This paper compares two power flow methods—back-and-forth co-simulation and direct full-system modeling—on both a small test system and the 150-bus Travis County synthetic grid. Results show that the back-and-forth approach achieves fewer iterations and shorter runtimes for complex systems, with little to no difference in final voltage profiles.Szymanowski Biography:Bart Szymanowski received his bachelor’s degrees in applied mathematics and physics from the University of Massachusetts Amherst in 2023. He is now pursuing graduate studies in power systems at Texas A&M University and has gained experience at ISOs across the country. His research focuses on transmission and distribution networks, aiming to advance the accuracy and effectiveness of current modeling and simulation tools.

event_title: ISEN Seminar: Asymptotically Optimal Clearing Control of Backlogs in Multiclass Processing Systems
event_summary: Dr. Ohad PerryAssociate ProfessorOperations Research & Engineering Management (OREM) DepartmentLyle School of EngineeringSouthern Methodist University
event_description: Abstract:We consider a dynamic scheduling problem for a processing system facing the problem of optimally clearing a large backlog of unsatisfied demand from several classes of customers (or jobs). We formulate the problem as a multiclass queueing model with a large initial queue and arrival rates that approximately equal the system’s processing capacity. The goal is to find a scheduling policy that minimizes a holding-and-abandonment cost during the transient period in which the system is considered congested. Because computing an exact solution to the optimal-control problem is infeasible, we develop a unified asymptotic approximation that covers, in particular, the conventional and the many-server heavy-traffic regimes. In addition to the generality and flexibility of our unified asymptotic framework, we also prove a strong form of asymptotic optimality, under which the costs converge in expectation and in probability. In particular, for the special two-class case, we prove that a static priority policy, which follows a discounted

event_title: ISEN Seminar: Finding Needles in a Haystack: Identifying Critical Data for Rare-Event and Digital Twin Simulation
event_summary: Dr. Eunshin ByonProfessor and Richard Wilson ScholarIndustrial and Operations Engineering DepartmentUniversity of Michigan
event_description: Abstract:In big data settings, identifying critical data and variables—essential for efficient computation, robust estimation, and explainable AI—is often like finding needles in a haystack. This talk explores how to locate such “needles” in stochastic simulation for estimating rare-event probabilities and in digital twin calibration, a problem of both theoretical and practical importance. Rare events typically occur under specific input conditions. Yet as dimensionality increases, the search space expands exponentially while the regions driving rare events occupy an increasingly sparse fraction of the overall volume. This phenomenon makes the design of efficient sampling strategies particularly challenging. We address this challenge using two variance reduction techniques: stratified sampling and importance sampling. For stratified sampling, we derive the optimal stratification structure for univariate settings and extend it via decision trees to develop a robust algorithm for multi-dimensional problems. For importance sampling, we propose a novel dimension-reduction method tailored to stochastic simulation. This approach balances concentrating on key variables with broader exploration, thereby reducing variance and improving estimator robustness. Finally, we discuss extensions to digital twin calibration, where massive datasets, high-dimensional parameters, and block-structured data introduce additional computational challenges.Bio:Dr. Eunshin Byon is a Professor and Richard Wilson Scholar in the Industrial and Operations Engineering Department at the University of Michigan, where she also serves as Director of the IOE Master’s Program. She earned her Ph.D. in the Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering from Texas A&M University in 2010 and holds B.S. and M.S. degrees from KAIST. Her research focuses on data science and AI, quality and reliability engineering, and uncertainty quantification. She has received multiple Best Paper Awards and recognitions from INFORMS and IISE, with research supported by the NSF as well as industry partners. She currently serves as a Department Editor for IISE Transactions and as a Senior Editor for the INFORMS Journal on Data Science.
event_category: faculty, researcher, staff, students

event_title: MSEN Seminar: Electrochemistry and the Molten State: from Materials Fundamentals to Processing
event_summary: Dr. Antoine AllanoreProfessor of Metallurgy in the Department of Materials Science and EngineeringMassachusetts Institute of Technology
event_description: Abstract:Metals and minerals are the basis of modern society, and their affordable and environmentally respectable extraction and recycling technologies are required. A global population of 9 billion people by 2050 along with supply chain disruptions provide unique opportunities for the deployment of new technologies for metals extraction and processing, when powered by electricity[1]. For commodity metals such as iron, aluminum and copper, this is inherently achieved via the molten state, supporting higher productivity and better-quality control[2]. This seminar highlights how materials science and engineering has a key role in enabling such transformation, starting with a survey of a subset of processes and the past contributions of the field, and the new frontiers investigated in our laboratory.Recent advances are then presented, pertinent to new process technologies such as electrolysis [3,4,5] or sulfidation for primary minerals separation and metal recycling [6,7,8,9], as well as scientific concepts and tools to access the physical-chemistry and thermodynamic of the molten state [10,11].Bio:Antoine Allanore is Professor of Metallurgy in the Department of Materials Science and Engineering and the recipient of the Heather N. Lechtman Chair at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Prof. Allanore earned a chemical process engineer diploma from École Nationale Supérieure des Industries Chimiques and a M.Sc. and a Ph.D. from Lorraine University.He joined the MIT in 2010 as a post-doctoral, after several years of service as research engineer for ArcelorMittal. In 2012, he was appointed the T.B. King Assistant Professor of Metallurgy in the Department of Materials Science and Engineering. He teaches thermodynamics and sustainable chemical metallurgy.His research has led to new process technologies that are under deployment around the world, including for the production of iron and steel by electrolysis without greenhouse gas emissions. He has been organizer of several TMS symposia dedicated to materials processing since 2012 and was a member of the editorial board of Metallurgical and Materials Transactions B between 2017 and 2023.He is the current director of the Center for Materials Research in Archaeology and Ethnology at MIT and recently earned the John Elliott Lectureship Award from the Association for Iron and Steel.

event_title: MSEN Seminar: Epitaxial Growth of Transition Metal Dichalcogenides – An Enabling Technology for Large Area 2D Devices
event_summary: Dr. Joan M. Redwing2D Crystal Consortium Materials Innovation Platform (2DCC-MIP), Department of Materials Science and EngineeringPennsylvania State University
event_description: Abstract:Monolayer and few-layer semiconducting Transition Metal Dichalcogenides (TMDs), exemplified by materials like MoS2 and WSe2, have garnered increasing interest for next generation electronics such as gate-all-around nanosheet transistors, neuromorphic devices and sensors/imagers heterogeneously integrated with silicon CMOS technology.The interest in semiconducting TMDs arises from their atomically thin nature and passivated van der Waals surfaces, however, realization of high-performance devices requires advances in TMD synthesis to provide wafer-scale films that can be readily integrated into devices via either direct growth or layer transfer methods.Our work has focused on the development of metalorganic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD) as a manufacturing- compatible approach for wafer-scale semiconducting TMDs. The TMDs are grown epitaxially on 2” diameter c-plane sapphire by MOCVD at elevated temperatures (>800 °C) to obtain high crystal quality. Nucleation of TMDs on sapphire is intimately tied to the surface structure and the growth chemistry which can be controlled to achieve unidirectional TMD domains with a significant reduction in mirror twin domains in coalesced films.In situ spectroscopic ellipsometry is demonstrated to be an effective real time monitor of TMD growth even at the sub-monolayer level which can be exploited to track surface coverage as a function of time under varying growth conditions. The ability to precisely control and modulate precursor flux during growth is used to synthesize in-plane heterostructures that enable localized exciton confinement and emission.Applications for wafer-scale TMD monolayers in nanoelectronics, sensing and photonics will be discussed.Bio:Joan Redwing is a Distinguished Professor of Materials Science and Engineering and Electrical Engineering at Penn State University. She currently serves as Director of the 2D Crystal Consortium, an NSF Materials Innovation Platform (MIP) national user facility that is focused on the synthesis and characterization of 2D materials for next generation devices.Her research focuses on crystal growth and epitaxy of electronic materials, with an emphasis on thin film and nanomaterial synthesis by metalorganic chemical vapor deposition.She currently serves as Vice President of the American Association for Crystal Growth and the International Organization for Crystal Growth.She is a fellow of the Materials Research Society, the American Physical Society, and the American Association for the Advancement of Science.She is an author on over 350 publications in refereed journals and holds 8 U.S. patents.

event_title: MSEN Seminar: Thermodynamic Design of Self-Organizing Interlayers for Dissimilar Joining
event_summary: Dr. Ian Daniel McCueAssistant Professor and the Morris E. Fine Junior Professor in Materials and Manufacturing, Department of Materials Science and EngineeringNorthwestern University
event_description: Abstract:Similar and dissimilar joining of shape memory alloys (SMAs) has gained increased attention in recent years, due to their use in aerospace, transportation, and biomedical industries. However, traditional joining methods (e.g., fusion welding) are challenging to apply to these materials because they lead to local weakening, formation of brittle intermetallic, and decreases in functional performance.Here, transient liquid phase (TLP) bonding is studied as a viable solution. TLP involves heating a joint to a temperature where interdiffusion produces a lower melting point liquid, which subsequently undergoes isothermal solidification to form a dense joint. TLP is currently used in aerospace for joining similar materials but has proved challenging to extend to dissimilar joining. In this talk, we will discuss how limitations in TLP can be overcome using CALPHAD-based techniques and path planning algorithms to guide phase evolution.We will also describe our ongoing experimental work on similar & dissimilar joints, which include microstructural and mechanical characterization. Although our use case is specific NASA, Houston, Texas to joining SMAs, these approaches are broadly applicable to any dissimilar joining process.Bio:McCue is a tenure-track Assistant Professor and the Morris E. Fine Junior Professor in Materials and Manufacturing at Northwestern University in the Department of Materials Science and Engineering.His research group focuses on designing materials for extreme applications – such as aerodynamic, radiation, and corrosion – and understanding how their microstructures evolve in these environments.He received his PhD degree in Materials Science and Engineering from Johns Hopkins University in 2015 and then held a postdoctoral appointment at Texas A&M University. Prior to joining Northwestern University, he was a Senior Scientist at the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory, working in the Research and Exploratory Development Department.He received a NASA Early Career Faculty Award in 2021 to develop a thermodynamic framework to guide the design of dissimilar bonding for shape memory alloys, and a DARPA Young Faculty Award in 2023 to develop a new high-strain rate mechanical test method.
