event_title: 2025 Texas New Fruit Growers Conference: Day 1
event_summary: The Texas New Fruit Grower’s Conference is aTexas A&M AgriLife Extension Serviceevent aimed at educating new and prospective fruit growers through classroom instruction, experiential learning, and peer-to-peer networking.
event_description: This one-and-a-half-day event exposes individuals with no previous farming or food production experience to an understanding of the unique challenges of managing a fruit orchard and vineyard.Participants will learn how to select an appropriate site, how to choose crops that grow successfully in their area of Texas, how to establish a vineyard or orchard and how to protect it from some of the unique weather and pest challenges that fruit growers encounter.The cost for the course is $130 per person. For AgriLife Extension employees the cost is $65. Online registration is available through Oct. 2 athttps://tx.ag/NFG2025.
event_category: training workshops, faculty, residents, staff

event_title: David McKnight ’73 Ranch Management University: Day 1
event_summary: The award-winningDavid McKnight ’73 Ranch Management Universityis scheduled for Oct. 20-24 at the Scotts Miracle-Gro Turf Facility.
event_description: The cost of the event is $525 for general registration, $325 for military, veterans, law enforcement and first responders, and $250 forTexas A&M AgriLifeemployees. Online registration is available athttps://tx.ag/RMU2025.This short course, named in honor of ranching enthusiast David McKnight, is a critical educational initiative designed to help new and inexperienced landowners understand the fundamentals of natural resource management. Through applied learning and foundational information, the program empowers participants to make financially sound decisions, optimize land productivity, and maximize long-term land stewardship.By putting the pieces together, landowners gain practical knowledge they can take back to their piece of Texas and apply with confidence.
event_category: speakers, forums, and conferences, training workshops, residents

event_summary: TheTexas A&M AgriLife Extension Serviceand theTexas State Soil and Water Conservation Boardin cooperation with theTexas Water Resources Institutewill host aTexas Watershed Stewardworkshop on the Big Elm Creek and other nearby watersheds on Oct. 20 in Cameron.
event_description: The free event is open to anyone interested in improving the region’s water quality. Participants must pre-register by visiting the Texas Watershed Steward website athttps://tws.tamu.edu/workshops/registration/or by calling 979-321-5935.The workshop will cover Big Elm Creek, Deer Creek, Pond Creek, Middle Yegua Creek and Brushy Creek.It will include a discussion on watershed systems, along with types and sources of water pollution. There will also be a group discussion on community-driven watershed protection and management and an overview of water quality as it relates to watershed management at the local level.

event_summary: TheTexas A&M AgriLife Extension Serviceand McLennan Community College will host a Taste of the Mediterranean diet cooking class Oct. 28 in Waco.
event_description: The cost of the class is $25 and online registration is available athttps://tx.ag/Mediterranean. Space is limited and the deadline to register is Oct. 26.The Mediterranean diet is a way of eating and preparing foods in the U.S. based on traditions from Italy, Greece and other countries that border the Mediterranean Sea.Plant-based foods including whole grains, vegetables, legumes, fruits and nuts, herbs and spices are the foundation of the diet. Fish, dairy, poultry and seafood are all eaten in moderation, and olive oil is a main source of fat in this type of diet.Rachel Esquivel, AgriLife Extensionfamily and community healthagent for McLennan County, will teach the class.

event_title: CDE - Innovative Dentistry: Exploring 3D Printing for New Practitioners
event_summary: Course SummaryThis introductory course is designed for dentists who are new to 3D printing technology. Participants will explore the transformative potential of 3D printing in modern dental practices, learning how this innovative technology can enhance precision, efficiency, and patient care. This course is ideal for dentists who have little to no experience with 3D printing and are interested in learning how to integrate this technology into their practice to improve patient outcomes and streamline operations.REGISTER:https://reg.learningstream.com/reg/event_page.aspx?ek=0069-0031-309d3f6d79ae472ab2c1785f98a9bdc3
event_description: ObjectivesUpon completion of this course, you will be able to:Understand the fundamentals of 3D printing technology and its application in the dental field.Identify the various uses of 3D printing in dentistry.Recognize the benefits of integrating 3D printing into dental practices.Evaluate the necessary equipment and software required to start using 3D printing in their practice.
event_category: training workshops, faculty, researcher, residents, staff, students, visitors, dallas

event_title: CDE - Providing Care to the Special Needs Patient
event_summary: Course SummaryCaring for patients with special health care needs comes with unique challenges that the dental clinician is not always prepared for. This course is designed to help give you the perspective and skills for treating, educating, and supporting patients with disabilities. We will review pertinent behavioral management principles and historical perspectives that will help you be successful in serving the special needs patient.REGISTER:https://reg.learningstream.com/reg/event_page.aspx?ek=0069-0031-b34458d519934f58adda08a5bb5110bb
event_description: ObjectivesUpon completion of this course, you will be able to:Review the history of disability around the world.Review common disability conditions the dental clinician may encounter.Learn behavioral management principles that will help special needs patients have a better dental experience.Review some of the most common treatment challenges and how to overcome them.
event_category: training workshops, faculty, researcher, residents, staff, students, visitors, dallas

event_summary: Antibiotic Stewardship: Policy, Practice, and ProcessesCourse Overview:This session will define the challenges with antibiotic use, enumerate the roles of dentists in the future of antibiotic stewardship, and discuss best practices in other healthcare professions. We will review the current evidence base for antibiotic use in dentistry and review best practices for dental clinicians. Participants will be shown an example of an antibiotic stewardship program that was implemented at the state level, and brainstorm programs and policies that have the potential to work in their state. Lastly, participants will discuss future policy state and national options for antibiotic stewardship.REGISTER HERE: https://reg.learningstream.com/reg/event_page.aspx?ek=0069-0031-863e5032344a46fd99a96b8a383c8339
event_description: Objectives:Upon completion of this course, you will learn:Define the roles of dentists and state dental directors in antibiotic stewardship.Describe evidence-based guidelines for antibiotic use in dentistry.Understand the mindset shift and influence clinical guidelines have on clinical practice.Critically evaluate and apply the guideline to treat tooth pain and swelling in adults who are not immunocompromised.Identify and utilize resources that can be used chairside to make clinical decisions for antibiotic stewardship.Develop strategies to implement practices chairside.Examine policy recommendations for antibiotic stewardship nationally.
event_category: campus life, speakers, forums, and conferences, training workshops, faculty, researcher, residents, staff, students, visitors, dallas

event_title: CDE - Bone Preservation Strategies Following Severe Traumatic Dental Injuries in Children
event_summary: Course SummarySevere traumatic dental injuries (TDIs) in young patients can result in unrestorable teeth or replacement resorption and ankylosis with the potential for infra-occlusion in growing children. Extraction is often the treatment rendered in these cases. When permanent teeth are subsequently extracted, long-term complications are likely. The supporting bone will be lost, creating the need for additional interventions later in life when the patient is ready for a more permanent option to rehabilitate the area. In the meantime, young, growing patients have limited prosthetic options if a tooth is lost. Bone preservation in young patients is of paramount importance. When patients are ready for definitive tooth replacement (eg. implant), previous bone preservation can make the process simpler and less costly as the need for bone and soft tissue augmentation may be minimal or unnecessary. This presentation will cover a series of clinical cases where bone preservation strategies were employed when treating young patients following severe TDIs. This presentation will emphasize how a multidisciplinary approach is paramount to achieve optimal results, where the endodontist needs to collaborate with periodontists, oral surgeons, orthodontists and general dentists.REGISTER:https://reg.learningstream.com/reg/event_page.aspx?ek=0069-0031-d1f4b6742b994ee897de8e0a2b173643
event_description: ObjectivesUpon completion of this course, you will be able to:Review types of trauma that can aid in the need for bone preservation.Understand the importance of bone preservation in the young, growing patient.Articulate options for bone preservation in young patients.Highlight the importance of multidisciplinary collaboration.
event_category: training workshops, faculty, researcher, residents, staff, students, visitors, dallas

event_description: ObjectivesUpon completion of this course, you will be able to:Develop a decision-making process that leads to a successful application of the appropriate lining material.Review best practices in the placement of a denture liner.

event_title: Riparian and Stream Ecosystem Workshop: Medina River Watershed
event_summary: This training will focus on the nature and function of stream and riparian zones and the benefits and direct impacts from healthy riparian zones. This workshop is being co-hosted by the Bandera County River Authority & Groundwater District, Texas A&M AgriLife Extension & Research and the Texas Water Resources Institute.
event_description: The riparian education programs will cover an introduction to riparian principles, watershed processes, basic hydrology, erosion/deposition principles and riparian vegetation, as well as potential causes of degradation and possible resulting impairment(s) and available local resources, including technical assistance and tools that can be employed to prevent and/or resolve degradation.RSVP by October 7, 2025These one-day trainings in watersheds across the state include both indoor classroom presentations and outdoor stream walks. Instructors are experts from the Bandera County River Authority & Groundwater District, Texas Parks and Wildlife Department, USDA Natural Resources Conservation Service, Texas A&M Forest Service and Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service.The goal is for participants to better understand and relate to riparian and watershed processes, the benefits that healthy riparian areas provide and the tools that can be employed to prevent and/or resolve degradation and improve water quality. At the conclusion of the training, participants will receive a certificate of completion.Continuing Education Units Available:Texas Department of Agriculture Pesticide Applicators License - 3 CEUsTexas Nutrient Management Planning Specialists - 6 hoursInternational Society of Arboriculture - 8.25 CEUs (Certified Arborist: 2.75, Municipal Specialist: 2.75, BCMA - Science: 0.75, BCMA - Practice: 2)Texas Forestry Association - 6 hoursSociety of American Foresters - 6 hoursSociety for Range Management – 7 CEUsCertified Crop Advisor- 7 CEUs (Nutrient Mgmt: 1, Soil & Water: 1.5, IPM: 1.5, Crop Mgmt: 2.5, Manure Mgmt: 0.5)Texas Board of Architectural Examiners “Acceptable for HSW credit”Texas Floodplain Management Association – 7 CECsThe program may also be used for CEUs for Professional Engineers.Check with your Chapter for Master Naturalist and Master Gardener to see if it is approved for your area. This course is approved for the Texas Waters Specialist certification program.Registration is required by October 7, 2025.A catered lunch will be available to participants for $15. Lunch can be paid for in advance by credit card or in cash on-site the day of the event. Participants may also choose to bring their own lunch. Dress is casual and comfortable for the weather as we will be outside along a nearby stream during the afternoon.For more information or questions please contact Alexander Neal atAlexander.Neal@ag.tamu.eduor 979-314-2351. This workshop is free because the program is funded through a Clean Water Act grant provided by the Texas State Soil and Water Conservation Board and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.Please join ourlistservor like our partnering organization onFacebookfor more information on future programs!
event_category: training workshops

event_title: Medina River Watershed Protection Plan Meeting
event_summary: The Texas Water Resources Institute, TWRI, invites local stakeholders to a public meeting to discuss the next steps for theMedina River Below Medina Diversion Lake Watershed Protection Plan(WPP) on Oct. 16 in Castroville.
event_description: The free public meeting will be from 1-3 p.m. at the Braden Keller Community Center, 1410 Amelia St, in Castroville.The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)recently acceptedthe WPP for the Medina River below Medina Diversion Lake as meeting EPA guidelines for watershed-based plans. The plan outlines a strategy to implement management measures that will help improve and protect water quality in the watershed.“Acceptance of the plan is a result of collaboration between watershed stakeholders, the San Antonio River Authority, and Texas A&M AgriLife and TWRI,” said Tina Hendon, TWRI program specialist. “Local residents, agricultural producers, business and industry representatives, city and county personnel and other interested parties provided valuable input for development of the plan.”With EPA’s recent acceptance, this meeting will focus on building momentum for implementation and will highlight the role of community partners in supporting healthy landscapes and clean water.Meeting highlightsThe agenda includes updates on social media engagement, outreach successes and challenges, and upcoming workshops and events from TWRI staff. Stakeholders will also be invited to provide feedback on outreach needs and to participate in the design of a new Medina River WPP logo, ensuring the plan has a clear identity that reflects the community it serves.Guest presentations will feature:Nathan Glavy, technical director,Greater Edwards Aquifer Alliance (GEAA), discussing GEAA support of local efforts and their “Building Healthy Landscapes” workshop.Kason Haby, technical assistance specialist, Texas Grazing Lands Coalition covering soil health and grazing land stewardship practices that benefit both producers and water quality.Lee Albee, owner and rancher, Southwest Farms, discussing generative agriculture on his operation and the services available to local producers.“Implementation is about more than just projects — it’s about people and partnerships,” said Mary Michael Zahed, TWRI program specialist. “This meeting is a chance for stakeholders to see how local organizations and producers are putting conservation into practice and to help shape the future of the watershed.”Funding for this effort is provided through a federal Clean Water Act Section 319(h) grant from theU.S. Environmental Protection Agency, administered by theTexas State Soil and Water Conservation Board.TWRI is aTexas A&M AgriLife Researchunit that brings together expertise from acrossThe Texas A&M University System.For more information, contact Zahed atmary.lipfordzahed@ag.tamu.eduor 979-314-8092. Read more about the watershed atmedina.twri.tamu.edu.

event_title: Davidson Creek Public Meeting and Expert Panel
event_summary: October 21:The Texas Water Resources Institute (TWRI) invites community members, landowners, and anyone with interest in local water quality to attend the fifth public meeting for the Davidson Creek Watershed Protection Plan (WPP), where hot spots for potential bacteria pollution will be presented and followed by a panel discussion featuring experts in watershed management and conservation practices.
event_description: The meeting will take place onTuesday, October 21, at 12:00 p.m.at the Burleson County Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service Office, 1516 FM 166, Caldwell, Texas.(Please note: the Extension Office is no longer located at the county courthouse.)There is no requirement for participants to have attended prior meetings, anyone interested can catch up by reviewing notes and presentations from previous meetings on the Davidson Creek website meetings tabhttps://davidson.twri.tamu.edu/meetings/.The event is hosted by the Davidson Creek Watershed Partnership in collaboration with Burleson County AgriLife Extension and aims to share critical location-based analysis that supports the ongoing development of the WPP. Attendees will learn how and where hot spots were located for potential bacteria loading across the watershed. The findings will help prioritize areas for targeted conservation efforts and Best Management Practices (BMPs). Attendees will also have the opportunity to ask questions from panel of experts on implementing BMPs across central Texas to improve water quality.Public input is strongly encouraged. Your voice and involvement are critical to the success of this plan.Funding for developing the Davidson Creek WPP is provided by the Texas State Soil and Water Conservation Board, through the State Nonpoint Source Grant Program.TWRI is part of Texas A&M AgriLife Research, Texas A&M AgriLife Extension and the College of Agriculture and Life Sciences at Texas A&M University.While RSVP is not required for attendance, please RSVP to the event by 10/16 so we can prepare materials and handoutshttps://forms.office.com/r/cuwYdUxVQL. For more information, contact Amanda Tague atamanda.tague@ag.tamu.edu. Read more about this watershed atDavidson.twri.tamu.edu.

event_title: Land Smart Workshop - Medina River Watershed
event_summary: Land Smart: A Guide to Small Acreage StewardshipOctober 25:Free workshop for new and small-acreage landowners in Medina River watershed in Castroville from 8:30 a.m. - 2:00 p.m.Registeronlineathttp://tx.ag/landsmart2025or call 830-426-2521 ext. 3.
event_description: Medina County is seeing many new faces as families move from city life to the countryside. To help small-acreage landowners understand their property and make informed decisions, the Texas Water Resources Institute (TWRI), Medina Valley Soil and Water Conservation District (MVSWCD), and other partners are hosting a workshop,Land Smart: A Guide to Small Acreage Stewardship,onSaturday, October 25, 2025, from 8:30 AM – 2:00 PM at the St. Louis Braden Keller Community Center in Castroville.The event is free and open to the public and includes breakfast and lunch.“It is easy to feel overwhelmed with the possibilities of what to do with new property and many new landowners in the Medina River Watershed are likely wondering, now what?” said Mary Michael Zahed, Medina River watershed coordinator, TWRI. “This workshop was designed especially for new landowners with those with 1-50 acres of land.”The workshop will cover topics such as understanding Medina County soils, water, and vegetation; land use options like livestock, wildlife, and beekeeping; tax benefits for agriculture and wildlife exemptions; and local programs and funding sources. Hands-on demonstrations, including a rainfall simulator and watershed model, will show conservation practices in action.A panel discussion will feature experts from theMedina Valley Soil and Water Conservation District, Texas Water Resources Institute, Texas Grazing Land Coalition, Wildlife Habitat Federation, USDA–Natural Resources Conservation Service, and USDA–Farm Service Agency.This is an opportunity for landowners to ask local experts questions about their property and land management options.“This workshop is designed to inform smaller-acreage landowners of their opportunities, including land management, conservation objectives, and tax options.” said Wayne Stein, MVSWCD Chair. “Come join us for food and knowledge.”The event isfreeand includes a light breakfast and lunch.Registration is requested to help plan meals.Register online athttp://tx.ag/landsmart2025or call 830-426-2521 ext. 3.Funding for this project is provided in part by theTexas State Soil and Water Conservation Board Stateas part of a Clean Water Act Section 319(h) Grant from theU.S. Environmental Protection Agency.TWRI is a unit ofTexas A&M AgriLife Researchthat brings together expertise from acrossThe Texas A&M University System.For more information, contact Zahed atmary.lipfordzahed@ag.tamu.eduor 979-314-8092. Read more about the watershed atmedina.twri.tamu.edu.
event_category: training workshops

event_title: Well Water Screening: Walker and Grimes County
event_summary: October 27:Water samples can be dropped off from 8:30 - 10:30 a.m. at the Grimes County AgriLife Extension office, 203 Veterans Memorial Drive, Navasota or the Walker County AgriLife Extension office, 102 Tam Road, Suite B, Huntsville.October 28:Results and educational meeting from 8:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. at the Huntsville Public Library, 1219 13thStreet, Huntsville.Cost:$15 per water sampleRSVPto Joel Pigg atj-pigg@tamu.edubyOctober 22to ensure adequate meeting room size.
event_description: Residents of Walker and Grimes County are invited to water well screenings and education meetings.TheTexas Well Owner Network, TWON, is holding an upcoming event on October 27-28. This program allows residents to have their private well water screened, as well as provide education training for groundwater protection. This event is hosted by the Bluebonnet Groundwater Conservation District, the Grimes County AgriLife Extension office and the Walker County AgriLife Extension office. It is open to the public and free to attend, lunch will be provided.Joel Pigg,Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Serviceprogram specialist, College Station, said the Texas Well Owner Network program is for Texas residents who depend on household wells for their water needs.“The TWON program was established to help well owners become familiar with Texas groundwater resources, septic system maintenance, well maintenance and construction, and water quality and treatment,” he said.Water samples will be screened for contaminants, including total coliform bacteria, E. coli bacteria, nitrate-nitrogen and salinity.Sampling instructionsPlease use a new bottle of water (12-20 ounces), pour out the contents and fill it with a water sample from your private water well. Take the sample from the spigot/hose bib nearest to the well head. Remove the water hose if there is one and take directly from the spigot/hose bib. If an inside faucet is used, you will need to remove the aerator on faucet before making the collection. Rinse and dry the exterior of the faucet to prevent exterior contamination of your water sample. If possible, wipe off with a Clorox-type towelette or paper towel wetted with a light bleach solution to kill any bacteria present on the faucet.Allow the solution to dry before sampling.Turn on the water full force and let it run at full force for two minutes or until you hear the pump start running. Reduce the water flow to a small stream and collect the sample.Refrigerate the sample and transport it to the workshop (in an ice chest) as soon after collection as possible. It is best to collect the day of the workshop if possible ;otherwise make sure the sample is kept cool and out of direct sunlight. Sample should be collected within 24 hours before the workshop to ensure accurate results.We encourage you to bring samples from all wells on your property; many participants that have water treatment equipment take samples before and after treatment to make sure the equipment is functioning properly. We need for you to label the sample with your name (if you bring more than one sample you also need to label the sample in a way to make sure you know which well the sample comes from). We will be screening for Nitrates, TDS (salinity) and bacteria (absence or presence of coliform and E. coli) with your sample.There will be a $15 per sample charge for this water well screening and you may bring as many samples as you would like.Pigg said it is essential for those submitting samples to be at the follow-up meeting to receive results, learn corrective measures for identified problems and improve their understanding of private well management.Water contaminants concernsPigg said research shows the presence ofE. colibacteria in water indicates that waste from humans or warm-blooded animals may have contaminated the water. Water contaminated withE. coliis more likely to also have pathogens that can cause diarrhea, cramps, nausea or other symptoms.The presence of nitrate-nitrogen in well water is also a concern, and water with nitrate-nitrogen at levels of 10 parts per million is considered unsafe for human consumption, he said.“These nitrate levels above 10 parts per million can disrupt the ability of blood to carry oxygen throughout the body, resulting in a condition called methemoglobinemia,” Pigg said. “Infants less than 6 months of age are the most susceptible to this.”Salinity, as measured by total dissolved solids, will also be determined for each sample, he said. Water with high levels may leave deposits and have a salty taste. Using water with high levels for irrigation may damage soil or plants.To learn more about the program or to find additional publications and resources, visittwon.tamu.edu. For more information on the water screening contact Pigg at 979-321-5946 orj-pigg@tamu.edu.The screenings are presented by Texas A&M AgriLife Extension andTexas Water Resources Institute, TWRI.Funding for TWON are through a Clean Water Act Section 319(h) nonpoint source grant provided by theTexas State Soil and Water Conservation Boardand theU.S. Environmental Protection Agency. The project is managed by TWRI, part ofTexas A&M AgriLife Research, AgriLife Extension and theTexas A&M College of Agriculture and Life Sciences.For more information specific to the workshop, contact the Grimes County AgriLife Extension office at 936-873-3907, Walker County AgriLife Extension Office at 936-435-2426, or the Bluebonnet Groundwater Conservation District at 936-825-7303 or Joel Pigg atj-pigg@tamu.eduor 979-321-5946.

event_summary: OPAS presentsChurchillin Rudder Theatre on November 6 (7:30 PM).  Tickets available atMSC Box Office.
event_description: Winston Churchill has just been awarded honorary U.S. citizenship by President John F. Kennedy. In recognition of this unprecedented occasion, The American-Oxford Society has asked the former Prime Minister to address them and discuss what this honor means to him. In this often funny, sometimes touching, and always engaging one-man show, veteran British actor David Payne brings Churchill to life onstage. Audiences will be delighted to hear of his exploits during the Boer War, his constant battles with Britain’s fellow politicians, and his special relationship with America and America’s presidents. But most telling of all, Churchill enlightens the audience with intimate and touching details of the two special women in his life—his wife Clementine and Queen Elizabeth.VisitChurchillfor more information about this program. Order tickets now at the Box Office. To see all of the shows coming to OPAS Season 53, visit our fullschedule page.Intimate Gatherings Series Sponsored byComfort Keepers, The Corrier Group, Sonic Bryan College Station

event_title: Graduate Consulting Career Series 1: Introduction to Consulting
event_summary: VirtualOnline only
event_description: This series introduces graduate students to the consulting profession. The first session focuses on what consulting is, jobs available, and the industry as a whole. Students will gain an in-depth view of the consulting world.Attendees will learn:• What is consulting and how it fits into the industry sector of professional services• Profiles of MBB, Big 4, and boutique consultancies• History of consulting; career ladders, including traditional and specialist• Consulting salaries• Overview of a consulting engagement.Attending this event and completing the reflection is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students.
event_category: campus life, general interest, international students, listening session, open houses receptions, speakers, forums, and conferences, training workshops, students, bryan-college station, canyon, dallas , fort worth, galveston, houston, mcallen, round rock, temple, washington d.c.

event_title: NACE Top 8 Skills: What are employers looking for?
event_summary: Virtual
event_description: For employers, career readiness plays an important role in sourcing talent, providing a means of identifying key skills and abilities across all job functions; similarly, career readiness offers employers a framework for developing talent through internship and other experiential education programs. Attend this workshop to learn about the skills employers are looking for and how to fold these skills into your candidacy.
event_category: campus life, general interest, open houses receptions, training workshops, students, bryan-college station, canyon, dallas , fort worth, galveston, houston, mcallen, round rock, temple, washington d.c.

event_title: Graduate Consulting Career Series 2: Introduction to Consulting
event_summary: VirtualOnline only
event_description: The second session focuses on finding a job in consulting. Students will be equipped with the search and networking tools and know how to craft a resume and cover letter to get into the interview stage at a consultancy.Attendees will learn:• How consulting recruiting works and how to leverage that to students’ advantage• Effectively networking with consultants, particularly at firms that have yet to identify TAMU as a target school• Crafting a resume that is quantitative and uses the Harvard Business School (HBS) format• Writing a cover letter that gets noticed by consultanciesAttending this event and completing the reflection is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students.
event_category: campus life, general interest, international students, listening session, open houses receptions, speakers, forums, and conferences, training workshops, students, bryan-college station, canyon, dallas , fort worth, galveston, houston, mcallen, round rock, temple, washington d.c.

event_summary: Virtual
event_description: This session is a collaboration between the Texas A&M Career Center, Texas A&M International Student & Scholar Services, and Fragomen, Del Rey, Bernsen, & Loewy, LLP for TAMU international students on work visa options and strategies for careers in the agricultural sector.
event_category: campus life, general interest, open houses receptions, training workshops, students, bryan-college station, canyon, dallas , fort worth, galveston, houston, mcallen, round rock, temple, washington d.c.

event_title: Graduate Consulting Career Series 3: Fit and Personal Experience Interviews
event_summary: VirtualOnline only
event_description: The third session focuses on the behavioral interview component in the consulting hiring process: fit and personal experience interviews (PEIs). Participants will come away from this session knowing how to navigate these specific types of interviews and craft compelling stories for interviewers.Attendees will learn:• What a fit interview and what makes it different than a typical behavioral interview• What is the McKinsey PEI• Doing a resume walk during a fit interview• Challenging fit questions• Bring hooks into stories• Handling interviewer cross-examination• Demonstrating the skills consulting firms are looking forAttending this event and completing the reflection is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students.

event_description: Make your resume more effective. This presentation goes beyond formatting guidelines to discuss techniques to make your resume and cover letter more successful. Includes what employers look for, personal branding, resume structure, and building better bullets

event_title: Campus to Career: Your Major = Career Options Galore!
event_summary: In-person
event_description: Needing to make a good first impression? Or do you need help with sending a professional email? Welcome to the first installment of the Campus to Career series! We will cover all things communication as a young professional. From emails to shaking hands, come check out this brand new series from the AGLS Career Center!
event_category: campus life, general interest, open houses receptions, training workshops, students, bryan-college station

event_title: Personal Marketing and Leveraging Your Graduate Degree
event_summary: HybridHHHhonly
event_description: Graduate students must learn how to confidently market themselves and their academic experiences to diverse professional audiences. This workshop provides tools for identifying and articulating your unique value through intentional branding and networking strategies.Attendees of this workshop will learn:• How to define a personal brand aligned with career goals• How to articulate your graduate-level skills to non-academic employers• Strategies for leveraging LinkedIn, digital presence, and professional communities• Tips for networking authentically and building a strong elevator pitchAttending this event and completing the reflection is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students.
event_category: campus life, general interest, international students, listening session, open houses receptions, speakers, forums, and conferences, training workshops, students, bryan-college station, canyon, dallas , fort worth, galveston, houston, mcallen, round rock, temple, washington d.c.

event_title: Graduate Consulting Career Series 4: Communicating Like a Consultant and Case Interview Introduction
event_summary: VirtualOnline only
event_description: The fourth session focuses on teaching participants how to organize their thoughts like a consultant, communicating in a way that consultants and clients prefer, and introduces the case interview process. Participants will leave this session with communication tools and an understanding of case interviewing.Attendees will learn:• What the Pyramid Principle is and how to use it to communicate verbally and in writing• Constructing a consulting slide deck• Creating consulting data visualizations; mutually exclusive, collectively exhaustive (MECE), and how to use them to structure information• Drill-down analysis and hypothesis testing in case interviewing• Applying mental math.Attending this event and completing the reflection is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students.
event_category: campus life, general interest, international students, listening session, open houses receptions, speakers, forums, and conferences, training workshops, students, bryan-college station, canyon, dallas , fort worth, galveston, houston, mcallen, round rock, temple, washington d.c.

event_description: Learn practical techniques and strategies to improve your interviewing skills, whether you’re experienced at interviews or have never had one.

event_title: Graduate Consulting Career Series 5: Casing Continued
event_summary: VirtualOnline only
event_description: The fifth session rounds up our discussion on case interviewing. Participants will leave the session with a thorough knowledge of casing with the ability to apply best practices to their own case interview preparation.Attendees will learn:• Three case frameworks, including profitability, business situation, and M&A• Synthesizing case data• Creating your own framework for advanced cases• Overview of a case• Closing a case and making a recommendation.Attending this event and completing the reflection is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students.

event_title: Graduate Students Industry Interview Strategy & Structure
event_summary: HybridOnline only
event_description: The industry interview process often feels unintuitive and confusing. This workshop shines a light on what to expect in the interview while providing a strategic framework to successfully navigate the interview process.Attendees of this workshop will learn:• The mindset one needs to successfully navigate the interview process to increase the chances of receiving a job offer• The typical steps in an interview process• How to align one’s knowledge, skills, and abilities with a role and communicate qualifications during a job interview, including how to anticipate questions• The various types of interviews (e.g., screening, finalist) and how to navigate each• Asking high-quality questions during the interview process to triangulate further responsesAttending this event and completing the reflection is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students.

Focusing on career development, join this workshop to learn more about best practices in leveraging AI in your job search; tangible takeaways: optimizing Chat GPT/Bard/etc. asks, LinkedIn Mock Interviewing, and recruiter feedback on AI from SoACE and NACE.

event_title: Graduate Students Navigating Common Interview Questions
event_summary: HybridOnline only
event_description: “Tell me about yourself?”“Where do you see yourself in 3 years?”“What is your greatest strength and where is an area you’d like to improve in?”These are questions often asked during job interviews, and there are ways to answer them authentically and competently. This workshop focuses on the mechanics of interviewing and teaches graduate students to interview with confidence.Attendees of this workshop will learn:• How to align themselves with a role when asked to describe themselves in an interview• Approaches to answering common job interview questions• Why certain interview answers are better than others• How to answer behavioral and situational questions with confidenceAttending this event and completing the reflection is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students.

event_title: Graduate Students - Resume Writing for Higher Education and Student Affairs
event_summary: HybridOnline only
event_description: Graduate students pursuing careers in Student Affairs or other areas of Higher Education bring unique skills in leadership, programming, assessment, teaching, and student development. This workshop helps students craft resumes that translate these experiences into compelling, result-oriented documents that resonate with hiring committees across departments in colleges and universities.Attendees of this workshop will learn:• How to structure and format a resume tailored for higher education roles• What content to include from assistantships, practicum, teaching, and leadership experiences• Strategies for showcasing student impact, assessment outcomes, and professional competencies• How to align language with functional areas such as residence life, career services, or academic advising• Tips for differentiating resumes for entry-level, coordinator, or specialist positionsAttending this event and completing the reflection is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students.
event_category: campus life, general interest, international students, listening session, open houses receptions, speakers, forums, and conferences, training workshops, students, bryan-college station, canyon, dallas , fort worth, galveston, houston, mcallen, round rock, temple, washington d.c.

event_title: Graduate Students Interviewing for Higher Ed Student Affairs, Staff, and Administrator Roles
event_summary: VirtualOnline only
event_description: Graduate students pursuing careers in Student Affairs or other areas of Higher Education bring unique skills in leadership, programming, assessment, teaching, and student development. This workshop continues from the earlier workshop on resumes and demonstrates how to navigate a staff interview in higher educationAttendees of this workshop will learn:• How to research a role and align one’s skills and experiences to the job for the interview• Strategies for both screening interviews and finalist visits on campus• How to navigate challenging questions for both entry-level and senior-level rolesAttending this event and completing the reflection is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students.

event_title: Graduate Students Creating a Biology Resume for Industry
event_summary: VirtualOnline only
event_description: Both bench skills and computational skills need to be properly highlighted on the resume for biology and other life science roles in industry. This workshop is a deep dive into how to create an impactful resume that can increase your chances of a callback.Attendees of this workshop will learn:• How to design a resume so recruiters and hiring managers can easily find the information they’re looking for and increase the chances of a callback• How to demonstrate skills and experiences for bench roles, scientific coordination roles, and scientific communication roles• How to discuss the scope and impact of experience without making information “too technical” for hiring authoritiesAttending this event and completing the reflection is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students.

event_title: Campus to Career: What’s the Career Center?
event_summary: In-person
event_description: Ever wondered what exactly the AGLS Career Center is here at Texas A&M? Well, look no further! We’ll go over all of the different services and resources offered to you through the AGLS Career Center. From demystifying who we are to how we can help you with your professional development, this presentation is all about how the AGLS Career Center helps you!
event_category: campus life, general interest, open houses receptions, training workshops, students, bryan-college station

event_title: Hear from Peers: AI vs the Pharmacy Expert: How Well can Students Evaluate the Work of Generative AI
event_summary: Facilitators:Charlotte Farris, PharmDIrma Lerma Rangel College of PharmacyDescription:How well can students evaluate a generative AI tools ability to complete a common evaluative task? Join for a discussion looking at an assignment testing students’ abilities to detect strengths and weakness of one tool when used to answer a complex drug information question.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1) Identify practical strategies and tools shared by peers to enhance teaching, learning, or research practices within your discipline or institution.2) Reflect on peer experiences to gain insights into overcoming common challenges and implementing innovative approaches in your own work.3) Engage in collaborative dialogue to build connections, share feedback, and explore opportunities for future professional development or partnership.Register Here:https://ers.tamu.edu/register.aspx?scheduleid=45383
event_category: training workshops, faculty, staff, bryan-college station

event_title: Using Generative AI as a Tool to Assist Building a Course
event_summary: Facilitators:Carlos Perez, Center for Teaching ExcellenceKelli Adam, Center for Teaching ExcellenceDescription:This interactive workshop explores how generative AI can support the course design process from start to finish.Participants will examine the course design cycle, identify key opportunities for AI integration, and consider the value these tools bring to course planning. Attendees will leave with strategies for using AI to design a course.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1) Describe the course design cycle.2) Identify potential integration points of generative AI in the course design cycle.3) Discuss the value of using these tools in building a course.Register Here:https://ers.tamu.edu/event/11462
event_category: training workshops, faculty, staff

event_title: Active Learning Bites: Introduction to Active Learning
event_summary: Facilitators:Michele Vick, Center for Teaching ExcellenceCarlos Perez, Center for Teaching ExcellenceDescription:Discover how active learning can transform student engagement and classroom dynamics. This introductory session will define active learning, break down its components, and present a variety of strategies. Begin brainstorming how these approaches can enrich your teaching, and leave with practical, actionable ideas to implement right away. This is the first workshop in our active learning series.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1) Define active learning2) Describe the different components of active learning3) Plan an activity using active learning strategiesRegister Here:https://ers.tamu.edu/event/11428
event_category: training workshops, faculty, staff

event_title: AI Tools to Help Boost Classroom Engagement
event_summary: Facilitators:Reem Hussein, Center for Teaching ExcellenceDescription:Discover how to use Generative AI tools to boost classroom engagement. This hands-on workshop will equip you with practical skills to create dynamic and interactive learning experiences. Participants will explore some AI tools including Notebook LM and HeyGen, each designed to enhance classroom engagement and capture student attention effectively.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1) Explore a variety of generative AI tools to use in the classroom (HeyGen and Notebook LM)2) Discuss use cases where these tools could be used in the classroom.3) Implement Universal Design for Learning Principles while using HeyGen and NotebookLM.Register Here:https://ers.tamu.edu/event/11383
event_category: training workshops, faculty, staff

event_summary: Facilitators:Graduate Teaching Consultants, Center for Teaching ExcellenceDescription:What should a syllabus contain? How does the tone of a syllabus affect students? This workshop outlines components of a student-centered syllabus and discusses common classroom problems that can be avoided or minimized by a well-constructed syllabus. Participants will receive several handouts to support their design of a syllabus. This workshop is open to graduate students and postdoctoral scholars.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1. Identify where to locate required and recommended elements regarding course design.2. Recognize aspects of course syllabus design supporting engagement, classroom management, and student learning.3. Construct a course syllabus that supports student engagement and learning.Register Here:https://ers.tamu.edu/register.aspx?scheduleid=44982
event_category: training workshops, students

event_title: Course Design Fall 2025 Series: Session 1 - Crafting Learning Outcomes, the Foundation of a Course
event_summary: Facilitators:Jean Layne, Center for Teaching ExcellenceCarlos Perez, Center for Teaching ExcellenceDr. Armanto Sutedjo, Center for Teaching ExcellenceFacilitators:Introduction to the course design cycle and learning outcomes as the foundation for a well-aligned course. Discover tools that support outcome creation/revision. Plan with course context such as level and class size in mind. See examples and practice writing/revising learning outcomes and receive feedback. Additionally, explore ways to share learning outcomes with students through Canvas. Begin working on your course alignment map.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1)Define course situational factors most relevant to the overall course plan.2) Create/revise learning outcomes that are student centered, meaningful, and measurable.3) Generate a second level learning outcome by session or topic related to a course level learning outcome.Register Here:https://ers.tamu.edu/event/11394

event_title: Purposeful Personalized Learning with Generative AI
event_summary: Facilitators:Dr. Armanto Sutedjo, Center for Teaching ExcellenceReem Hussein, Center for Teaching ExcellenceDescription:This hands-on workshop guides instructors through the principles of personalized learning, emphasizing intentional design and learner agency.Participants will explore strategies for engaging students as co-designers in their learning journeys and discover how generative AI tools, especially those available through Texas A&M University can support differentiated instruction and adaptive learning. By the end of the session, participants will design a personalized learning module that integrates generative AI to meet diverse learner needs with clear instructional intent.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1) Discuss the principles of personalized learning.2) Explore strategies for engaging students as co-designers in personalized learning experiences using generative AI.3) Design a personalized learning module that integrates generative AI to meet diverse learner needs with clear instructional intent.Register Here:https://ers.tamu.edu/event/11439

event_title: Active Learning Bites: Thinking Routines to Promote Active Learning
event_summary: Facilitators:Michele Vick, Center for Teaching ExcellenceCarlos Perez, Center for Teaching ExcellenceDescription:As part of our Active Learning Workshop Series, this session introduces thinking routines—simple, flexible instructional strategies that promote active learning, fostering engagement, reflection, and deeper understanding. Discover how these routines can be used to spark curiosity, support student-centered assessments, and make thinking visible across a range of educational contexts. Explore a menu of practical options and begin identifying routines you can incorporate into your own teaching right away.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1) Define thinking routines2) Discuss how thinking routines promote active learning.3) Select two thinking routines that they can use in their own educational contextRegister Here:https://ers.tamu.edu/event/11430

event_title: Hear from Peers: Developing AI Perspectives and Competencies in the Context of An Introductory Ecology Course
event_description: Facilitators:Dr. Ben Wu - ProfessorCollege of Agriculture & Life SciencesDescription:AI competencies are essential for future success of our students. It is challenging but we need to design learning for developing AI competencies in each of our disciplinary contexts. We will share our efforts to facilitate student reflections on the role of AI in their career success beyond college and their needs and concerns for developing AI competencies in college, and our incremental efforts to incorporate AI competencies in the context of an introductory ecology course.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1) Identify practical strategies and tools shared by peers to enhance teaching, learning, or research practices within your discipline or institution.2) Reflect on peer experiences to gain insights into overcoming common challenges and implementing innovative approaches in your own work.3) Engage in collaborative dialogue to build connections, share feedback, and explore opportunities for future professional development or partnership.Register here:https://ers.tamu.edu/event/11528

Dellinger, Center for Teaching ExcellenceDescription:In this interactive session, participants will explore principles of heutagogy to cultivate lifelong learning. Through discussions and practical activities, participants will examine how heutagogical practice can enhance learner agency in higher education. Participants will also assess their own courses to identify meaningful ways to integrate self-determined and self-regulated learning to support students to take ownership of their learning journey.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1) Understand principles of heutagogy, self-determined learning, and self-regulated learning.2) Examine use cases for the higher education setting.3) Assess their courses for practical ways to integrate self-determined and self-regulated learning principles.Register Here:https://ers.tamu.edu/event/11377

event_title: Level Up Your Canvas Course: Utilizing Canvas Assignments & Quizzes
event_summary: Facilitators:Reem Hussein, Center for Teaching ExcellenceDr. Sherry Lin, School of Public HealthDescription:Take your course management to the next level by exploring how Canvas assignments and quizzes can streamline your teaching and enhance the student experience. In this hands-on session, participants will compare the benefits of Canvas tools versus traditional methods like email and paper submissions, learn how to build assignments with clear expectations and rubrics, and configure quiz settings that align with their assessment goals. Leave with practical strategies you can apply immediately to create a more efficient and engaging digital classroom.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1) Compare the advantages of Canvas tools versus traditional methods (email, paper) for instruction delivery and grade management2) Create assignments in Canvas with clear instructions, deadlines, and submission requirements with rubrics3) Configure quiz settings, including question types, time limits, and feedback options appropriate for their assessment goalsRegister Here:https://ers.tamu.edu/event/11374

event_title: TREC Cancer Prevention Clinicogenomic Registry Facility Core: A Two-Year Update
event_summary: A seminar-style update on the purpose, progress, and future plans for the Texas A&M Regional Center of Excellence in Cancer (TREC) Cancer Prevention Clinicogenomic Registry (CPCR) Facility Core. The seminar will be hosted in-person at theTexas A&M Medical Research Education Building, Room #1403,at the Texas A&M Health Science Center.Enjoy the opportunity to learn more about how TREC fosters the development of early-career investigators in cancer research, attracts outstanding cancer researchers to Texas A&M University, and fosters an interactive environment that promotes productive research collaborations. We will also discuss TREC’s collective goal to incentivize the development of cancer research programs with national and international impact and how TREC aims to achieve this goal.In-person attendance of this seminar is preferred as this facilitates high-quality conversation, but remote attendance is available via Zoom.The Texas A&M Regional Center of Excellence in Cancer is proudly supported by the Cancer Prevention and Research Institute of Texas (RP230204).
event_category: speakers, forums, and conferences, faculty, researcher, students, bryan-college station

event_title: The CIRTL Network Presents: Exploring Teaching Careers at Research Universities with CIRTL Alumni
event_summary: Faculty members who primarily teach, rather than do research, have become increasingly important for delivering courses to STEM undergraduates. Learn about the teaching faculty career path and ask questions of CIRTL alumni who are junior teaching faculty in this online panel event. Panelists will discuss the rewards and challenges of these positions, the opportunities for stability and advancement, and how non-tenure line faculty live in a research department. This is the first event in our four-part series “Exploring Career Paths with CIRTL Alumni.”
event_description: For more information on how to register for this event, please clickhere.
event_category: academic calendar, faculty, staff, students, bryan-college station

event_title: The CIRTL Network Presents: Exploring Teaching Careers at Teaching Intensive Universities with CIRTL Alumni
event_summary: Nationally, more undergraduates are educated at community colleges, liberal arts colleges, and specialized BS and MS universities than at research universities. These faculty become leaders at their institutions, usually serve as advisers as well, and may engage in some research. Learn about what it’s like to teaching at a teaching-intensive university and ask questions of CIRTL alumni who are teaching at these institutions in this online panel event. Panelists will talk about how much teaching they do, opportunities for leadership and advancement, and more. This is the second event in our three-part series “Exploring Career Paths with CIRTL Alumni.”
event_description: For more information on how to register for the event, please clickhere.

event_title: The CIRTL Network Presents: Examining and Analyzing Culturally Sustaining Pedagogy in Post-Secondary Contexts
event_summary: In the current U.S. political climate, where diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) initiatives face increasing scrutiny and legislative challenges, learning about culturally sustaining pedagogy (CSP) is more crucial than ever. Participants will learn the importance of using instructional strategies that affirm and sustain the cultural and linguistic identities of diverse students and how to foster a dynamic learning environment using CSP principles. Through collaboration and discussion, participants will identify and apply these principles as well as reflect on their own cultural identities and biases, challenge dominant narratives, and promote critical thinking in their classrooms. By the end of this workshop, participants will be prepared to:Identify How CSP supports teaching and learning in higher educationApply CSP principles to participant’s discipline or field of studyDifferentiate Between CSP and Non-CSP practices in teaching and learningPlan One or more course-related materials or activities using CSP principles
event_description: For more details on how to register for this event, please clickhere.
event_category: academic calendar, faculty, staff, students, bryan-college station

event_title: The CIRTL Network Presents: Overcoming Learning Helpless: Helping Students to Develop Strong Team Skills Through Emotional Intelligence
event_summary: Experience a “failed” team meeting that rehearses the experience that many students experience working on teams. Through a discussion of the theory of “learned helpless”, participants will learn how to empower our students to overcome and transform such experiences through the practice of emotional intelligence and the practice of effective team communication techniques. By the end of this workshop, participants will be prepared to:Understand the most common team dysfunctions students experience when working together on teams.Demonstrate emotional intelligence and effective communication skills to overcome poor team dynamics.
event_description: For more information on how to register for this event, please clickhere.
event_category: academic calendar, faculty, staff, students, bryan-college station

event_title: The CIRTL Network Presents: Exploring Academic Careers Beyond the Professoriate with CIRTL Alumni
event_summary: People who hold advanced degrees in STEM disciplines serve in many roles across academia – from administration and research support, to teaching centers and advising – where their preparation in teaching as well as their analytical and organizational skills are invaluable. Learn what some of these professions are like and ask questions of CIRTL alumni who work in these roles in this online panel event. Panelists will talk about their specific positions, their pathway to those positions, and the value of remaining connected to academia. This is the third event in our three-part series “Exploring Career Paths with CIRTL Alumni.”

event_title: The CIRTL Network Presents: Leveraging Strengths of Neurodiverse Students in the Classroom
event_summary: Many times the discussion around learning and neurodiversity is deficit based. While it is important to consider the very real learning challenges that many neurodiverse students face in higher education, it is equally critical to highlight the numerous strengths associated with different neurotypes such as ADHD, learning disabilities, autism, mental health challenges and consider ways to help students leverage strengths for learning. This workshop will provide participants with an overview of neurodiversity and explore what a strength based and neuroaffirming perspective entails. Participants will consider how learning environments can interact with neurodiversity to mobilize strengths or heighten challenges, and explore neuro-affirming instructional strategies to lower unintentional barriers to learning. By the end of this workshop, participants will be prepared to:Describe the tenets of a neurodiversity affirming paradigm and some neurodiversity related strengths and challengesIdentify some neuro-affirming instructional strategies that can help to mobilize neurodiversity-related strengths and lower learning barriersAnalyze your current instructional approach for neuro-affirming strategies that you currently utilizing or could integrate into your teaching

event_title: Colloquium Series: Michael Collins and Rachel Cicoria
event_summary: This is an in-person event, offering our fellows an opportunity to discuss their research with colleagues from different disciplines. However, the Glasscock Center is committed to providing access, when possible, to members of our community who are unable to attend in person for medical or other access reasons. Therefore, if you are a member of the Texas A&M community and need to attend virtually, please contact the Glasscock Center at least two working days prior to the event, so that we can work with IT to arrange access.
event_description: Presenters:Michael Collins, Associate Professor | English“The Imprisonment Dilemma”Rachel Cicoria, Ph.D. Student | Philosophy“Aristotle’s Barbarian, Las Casas’s Convert, and the Birth of Race”Abstracts:CollinsMore information forthcoming.CicoriaMore information forthcoming.Chair: Madelaine Setiawan | HistoryPlease note that this is not a lecture, and thus, is not suited for class attendance. The Colloquium Series is intended to provide the presenter with a forum to discuss their research and receive feedback from colleagues and peers.

event_title: Visual Arts and the Thought of The Anthropocene (Day 1)
event_summary: InternationalColloquiumPresented by the Humanities and the Anthropocene Initiative at the Melbern G. Glasscock Center for Humanities Research
event_description: In navigating the conundrum unleashed by the Anthropocene, visual artists employ a multiplicity of frameworks to think through the complexities of our current predicament. Echoing Goya’s painting of a dog trying to climb up and out of a wall of mud—a reminder of our inseparability from the earth’s myriad constituents, including today, alas, microplastics and toxic pollutants—the Colloquium proposes a debate on visual arts and environmental change, slow and geo-cinema, geo-photography, image surveillance…NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL GUESTS:Tatjana Gajic, Associate Professor Hispanic and Italian Studies, University of Illinois-ChicagoPatricia Keller, Professor Spanish and Comparative Literature, Cornell UniversityMonica Lopez, Associate Professor Spanish and Humanities, Reed CollegeEliza Mizrahi, Independent Scholar Art and Culture, Universidad Iberoamericana, MexicoCristina Moreiras-Menor, Kathleen M. About the Aggie Lyceum:The Aggie Lyceum is a non-profit, non-partisan civil discourse, media literacy, and citizen engagement program that takes its name and inspiration from the Texas Lyceum and practices “civic friendship.”Together We DineThis event is a partnership with Common Ground Texas and Project Unity. Together we will host a dinner and facilitated conversation about the problem of polarization. According to Common Ground Texas, “This event is designed to unite people from different backgrounds to share a meal and engage in open, honest conversations. The goal is to break down barriers, foster understanding, and highlight the common ground we all share—despite our different political beliefs.”Advance Registration is required.

event_summary: Learn from an Aggie engineer who implements groundbreaking technology to improve business efficiency.
event_description: Taha Raja is a seasoned entrepreneur and principal at three companies: FMW Fasteners, Power Cloud Consulting LLC, and Brambleberry Services & Tours. He has a proven track record of success in building and growing businesses across multiple industries.Taha emigrated to the United States from Dar Es Salaam, Tanzania in 1983. He graduated from Texas A&M University in 1992 with a BS in Aerospace Engineering and began his career at NASA. After a few years, he transitioned to the software industry, where he held various leadership roles.In 1993, Taha acquired his first business, The UPS Stores. He successfully grew the company to include seven locations in the Greater Houston Area. In 2006, he and two partners purchased FMW Fasteners, a local fastener distributor. Taha transformed FMW Fasteners into a national online distributor of fasteners, achieving significant revenue and margin growth.Taha’s success at FMW Fasteners led him to start Power Cloud Consulting, an ERP consulting firm that helps ecommerce distributors implement automation, ERP systems, and efficiencies. Power Cloud Consulting has grown to over 50 employees across three countries.Taha is also a principal at Brambleberry Services & Tours, a side project where he organizes wildlife photo tours to East Africa.Taha is a passionate traveler and photographer. He has visited over 92 countries and continues to pursue his hobbies while leading his three companies. Taha is married to Lubaina and has two children, Jamila and Husein.

event_title: Engineering Graduate Programs Informational (Virtual) - Domestic Students
event_summary: Learn about the graduate engineering programs offered at Texas A&M University without leaving the comfort of your home. During Virtual Grad Preview, you can speak with a College of Engineering graduate advisor and learn about all of the opportunities available within ourengineering departments.Sign up for our Virtual Grad Preview!Morning Session|Afternoon Session
event_description: Session 1:10 a.m. - Noon (CST)Session 2:2 - 3 p.m. (CST)Why Attend?Live chat with graduate advisors about our engineering graduate degree programsLive chat with current engineering graduate students to learn more about the student perspective of graduate life at Texas A&MFind out more about graduate admissions, degree plans, faculty, research opportunities, funding opportunities, and academic and student lifeThe Texas A&M College of Engineering is a globally-recognized institution, with our graduate programs ranked 8th among public institutions (U.S. News & World Report, 2020). We offer 15 graduate programs, with many nationally ranked, and we want to provide opportunities for students around the world to learn more about what Texas A&M can offer and what it means to be an Aggie Engineer.Texas A&M’s Aggie Network is unlike any other, and the opportunities and resources we can provide will enhance the value of your engineering degree. We believe it is a special experience to earn a degree at Texas A&M, which is why we have developed a virtual fair and created an opportunity for you to speak with our graduate advisor team and learn more about what the Texas A&M experience is all about.Frequently Asked QuestionsWhat is a Virtual Grad Fair?This is your opportunity to chat with Texas A&M graduate advisors about anything related to Texas A&M’s graduate school. Our advisors can fill you in on department-specific admission expectations, facilities and labs, funding, research, student organizations, and more.Do I need to register for this event?Yes, you will need to register to attend the event. You can register here.Who will I be able to chat with during the virtual event?Each participating department will have two advisors available to chat. Our graduate advisors are frequently thought of as the first point-of-contact for everything related to their respective graduate degree program. They are knowledgeable about every aspect of their program, including their admission requirements, faculty, labs, funding opportunities, and more. Departments vary in what they are looking for in students and what they can offer to you, which is why the graduate advisor is the best person to ask for specifics.Why should I attend this event?Often times, students chat with university representatives who are knowledgeable about the university as a whole, but they may not have specific knowledge about individual departments. Each graduate advisor represents one department, and therefore, they are incredibly knowledgeable about everything related to that department. The opportunity to chat with our graduate advisors before you arrive on campus is invaluable, as they can fill you in on department-specific admission expectations, facilities and labs, funding, student organizations, and more. Our graduate advisors are the best people to talk to when you want to know the small details about a program that make it unique.Can I log-in to the event at a later date?Yes. While our graduate advisors will only be available for the advertised times, you may still log-in to the event for 30 days and look at any booth materials they have uploaded for you.Can I come and go during the event?Yes. You may log-in to the event at any point while the event is live and chat with our graduate advisors. After the event ends, you may still log-in and access the materials at their booths for 30 days.Do you have any on-campus visits or events?We currently do not have any on-campus events planned; however, we do have anundergraduate research programthat is open to domestic undergraduates interested in graduate school. This program provides the opportunity for students to work with Texas A&M researchers, and we provide housing, a scholarship, and a travel stipend.
event_category: students

event_summary: Hear from a lifelong entrepreneur and branding specialist.
event_description: John (JP) McDade is the founder and visionary behind Already Design Co., a Dallas-based design, manufacturing, and fulfillment company. The son of a blue-collar baggage handler and a secretary, JP developed a strong work ethic and a keen sense for opportunity. In high school, he launched his first venture, Dr. Kleen, a specialized janitorial service focused on sanitizing medical facilities. Over seven years, he successfully scaled and subsequently sold the business, using the proceeds to fund his undergraduate studies at the University of Texas at Arlington and later earn an MBA from the University of Notre Dame.Before college, JP met his future wife and business partner, Joan. Together, they co-founded Already Design Co. in 1989, building it into a multi-faceted enterprise with a reputation for transforming ideas into fully realized products and brands. Under JP’s leadership, the company launched numerous brands including Puppet Planet (toys), YUMS (sneakers), It’s Lit (LED stadium items), to name a few. Already Design Co. also serves a wide array of clients including professional sports leagues to premium and luxury brands.Today, Already Design Co. spans over 60 product categories and offers comprehensive, start-to-finish services including concept development, design, manufacturing, and global distribution. With creative direction led by iconic Dallas graffiti artist Tex Moton, JP’s longtime collaborator of 30 years, the company brings a distinct blend of artistry and execution to every project.
event_category: listening session, speakers, forums, and conferences, students, bryan-college station

event_summary: Meet Brian Cline, Founder & CEO of Lumoniq, the engineer revolutionizing short-range optical communications.
event_description: Brian Cline is a computer hardware designer and researcher who transitioned into a deep-tech entrepreneur and founder. His career has been rooted in computer design and technology pathfinding, with a focus on shaping the future of semiconductor and non-semiconductor technologies to enable more efficient, faster, and energy-conscious computing systems.He brings extensive expertise in VLSI and physical design, with a specialization in translating and co-optimizing across system architecture, processor micro-architecture, physical implementation, and down to the foundational technology layers—devices and interconnects. His experience spans ASIC chip and IP design, as well as emerging technologies such as advanced MOSFETs (e.g., GAA, CFET), non-volatile memories (e.g., MRAM), EUV lithography, and 2.xD/3D-ICs. His research portfolio has centered on co-optimizing computing systems alongside these cutting-edge technologies.Cline has authored approximately 60 research papers, accumulating over 2,800 citations and achieving an h-index of 24 as of February 2025. He also holds a robust intellectual property portfolio, with more than 30 filed inventions.As a founder, he has expanded his capabilities to include early-stage fundraising, business planning and forecasting, and operational leadership. He co-founded a deep-tech hardware startup aimed at commercializing a disruptive emerging technology designed to overcome longstanding limitations in computing systems and chip design. Further details about the venture are expected to be shared in the near future.
event_category: listening session, speakers, forums, and conferences, students, bryan-college station

event_title: MSEN Seminar: Liquid Crystalline Elastomers: Soft Materials with Muscle-Like Responses
event_summary: Dr. Timothy J. WhiteThe Gallogly Professor of EngineeringUniversity of Colorado Boulder
event_description: Abstract:From the phones in our pockets to the televisions on our walls, liquid crystalline materials have transformed how we live and interact with technology. A fascinating branch of this materials family are liquid crystalline elastomers (LCEs). LCEs merge the molecular order of liquid crystals with the elasticity of polymers. The result is a class of soft materials that can bend, twist, and contract-like muscle when stimulated by heat, light, or electric fields.In this seminar, I will describe how molecular design, supramolecular interactions, and advanced processing approaches are used to control and amplify the remarkable responsiveness of LCEs.I will highlight recent efforts in 3D printing and alignment that expand their capabilities, and I will emphasize how these “soft muscles” are inspiring new applications in robotics, adaptive optics, and health care.Bio:Timothy J. White is the Gallogly Professor of Engineering at the University of Colorado Boulder. Tim received his Ph.D. in Chemical and Biochemical Engineering in 2006 from the University of Iowa and subsequently joined the Air Force Research Laboratory where he served as a Senior Research Engineer and Technology Advisor of the Photonic Materials Branch.In 2018, Tim joined the faculty at the University of Colorado Boulder. Tim leads the “Responsive and Programmable Materials” Group, pursuing research generally focused on programming functional responses in organized materials. Prof. White has more than 200 papers in peer-reviewed journals.Dr. White has been honored with the 2019 Soft Matter Lectureship, 2016 Materials Research Society “Outstanding Young Investigator” award, the 2013 SPIE Early Career Achievement award, the 2013 American Chemical Society PMSE Division Award for “Cooperative Research in Applied Polymer Science”, and the 2012 Air Force Early Career Award.
event_category: speakers, forums, and conferences, faculty, researcher, students, bryan-college station

event_title: MSEN Seminar: Studying Optical Properties of Hexagonal Boron Nitride using Electron Beams
event_summary: Dr. Cong SuAssistant professor in the Department of Materials Science and Department of Applied PhysicsYale University, New Haven, CT
event_description: Abstract:Hexagonal boron nitride (hBN), despite its structurally simple lattice, continues to be the subject of debate regarding its bandgap nature—whether it is direct or indirect—and its potential for quantum applications remains under active exploration.In this talk, I will present our recent advances in probing and engineering quantum emitters in hBN using cathodoluminescence, as well as in directly mapping its band structure via momentum-resolved electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS).Our results reveal a direct optical bandgap that exceeds previously reported values, along with the discovery of a photon-like excitonic band in the lowest excitonic state. These findings not only shed light on the fundamental optical properties of hBN but also pave the way for leveraging its wide bandgap and excitonic behavior in emerging quantum photonic technologies.Bio:Dr.Cong Su is an assistant professor in the Department of Materials Science and Department of Applied Physics at Yale University. He is also affiliated to Yale’s Energy Science Institute and Center for Materials Innovation.Cong was a Kavli Postdoctoral Fellow (Heising-Simons Junior Fellow) at UC Berkeley, and he got his Ph.D. from MIT and his bachelor’s from Peking University.Cong’s research focuses on atom control using electron beam, photonics and interfaces in semiconductors, and 2D materials synthesis.
