event_summary: Organic Division Seminar Series
event_description: Harnessing the potential of main-chain dipoles in polymers: New frontiers for physical organic chemistryThe core of physical organic chemistry is the relation of an organic (macro)molecule’s chemical structure to its reactivity/properties. This simple concept is a powerful tool to understand fundamental mechanisms, solve problems, improve sustainability, and establish design principles across a wide variety of fields. The Lamb group takes a physical organic approach to problems at the interface of polymer science and catalysis to transform how materials are made and un-made. Much of our work has been on polyoxazolidinones (POxa), which are an emerging polyurethane subclass for high-performance thermoplastic/electronic applications that have high thermal stability due to the five-membered heterocycles incorporated into the polymer backbone. We address many synthetic limitations of POxa and systematically investigate their structure-property relationships, particularly the effect of the strong, oriented Oxa dipole on material properties.
event_category: general interest, speakers, forums, and conferences, bryan-college station

event_title: Joaquín Rodríguez López, University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign
event_summary: Student-Invited Analytical Seminar
event_description: Putting a New Spin on Redox Intermediate and Reactive Oxygen Species Detection: Radicals Found in Unexpected PlacesElucidating and controlling the interfacial reactivity of oxygenated intermediates is key to a broad scope of electrochemical studies of catalysts, sensors, and energy storage. In this talk, I will introduce new methods for scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) detection of radical oxygenated intermediates and other reactive oxygen species (ROS) during the oxidation of water[1] the detection of oxygen evolution in degrading metal-oxide electrodes [2], and the direct detection of singlet oxygen[3]. I will then describe how in sonicated water microdroplets the generation of ROS points to new ways to promt redox reactivity [4]. Finally, I will also touch on the use of electrochemical automation to explore electrocatalysis.[5][1] J. Am. Chem. Soc.2022, 18896; [2]J.Electrochem. Soc.2022, 086501; [3]J. Am Chem. Soc.2024, 8847; [4]J. Am. Chem. Soc.2025, 11851; [5]Digital Discovery2024, 1812.
event_category: general interest, speakers, forums, and conferences, bryan-college station

event_summary: Organic Division Seminar Series
event_description: Taming nitrene reactivity with silver catalystsOver 80% of pharmaceuticals on the market contain at least one carbon-nitrogen (C–N) bond, as do many agrochemicals and bioactive natural products. Thus, methods to directly introduce nitrogen into simple precursors in an efficient, selective manner are of interest. The prevalence of C–H bonds make them ideal for direct functionalization to value-upgraded compounds; however, it can be challenging to target one specific C–H bond. Our group harnesses unusual features of silver(I) salts supported by diverse N-dentate ligands to catalyze selective nitrene transfer (NT) reactions that convert C–H bonds to C–N bonds in a tunable manner. Selected design principles and computational insights that underpin our ability to predictably tune the chemo-, site-, and stereoselectivity of silver-catalyzed NT will be presented, along with synthetic applications.

event_title: Public Talk by Dr. Judd Kessler
event_summary: Wharton economist and market designer Judd Kessler pulls back the curtain on hidden markets that determine who get what in everyday life - and how to tip scales in our favor.Join the Departments of Economics and Agricultural Economics for a public talk by Dr. Judd Kessler who will discuss his new book,Lucky by Design: The Hidden Economics You Need to Get More of What You Want.This event will include a reception, complimentary copies ofLucky by Design, and a book signing by Dr. Kessler.
event_description: Wharton economist and market designer Judd Kessler pulls back the curtain on hidden markets that determine who get what in everyday life - and how to tip scales in our favor.When should you enter a lottery to increase your odds of winning? Who gets priority for a life-saving organ donation?These outcomes are not a matter of luck. Instead, they depend on how we navigate hidden markets that arise to decide wo gets what when many of us want something and there isn’t enough to go around. Every day we play in these markets, yet few of us fully understand how they work.In familiar markets, what we get depends on how much we’re willing to pay. Hidden markets do not rely on prices: you can’t buy your way in to a better position. Instead, what you receive hinges on the rules by which the market operates and the choices you make in them.Judd Kessler has spent a career studying and designing these very markets. Now, he reveals the secrets of how they work and how to maneuver in them. Whether you want secure a spot in an oversubscribed college course or do your fair share of the household chores (but not more), this must-read guide will show you how to getLucky by Design.

event_title: University Libraries presents: Introduction to EndNote
event_summary: EndNote software helps you collect, organize, and format references to articles, books, and other publications during the research and writing process. This workshop is for anyone who wants to learn EndNote, including undergraduate students, graduate students, staff, and faculty. Currently affiliated Texas A&M University students, faculty and staff can obtain your free copy at https://software.tamu.edu/. Select EndNote from the list of available software and go through the checkout process in order to get the link, but you will not be charged because it is free. Be sure to follow the directions when installing. We suggest installing the software and ensuring it opens the day before the workshop since it takes time order, install, and ensure that it is ready to go.By the end of the class, participants will be able to:1. Summarize what EndNote is and how it can assist with organizing and creating citations.2. Explain how to get the EndNote software.3. Create an EndNote library and add citations manually and through searching databases.4. Find full-text or attach PDFs for citations within EndNote.5. Manage an EndNote library by creating groups.6. Use EndNote extension within Word to insert in-text citations, edit them, and change citation styles.Register HereAttending and actively participating in this event, and completing its reflection is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students.

This workshop is a deep dive into how to create an impactful resume that can increase your chances of a callback.Attendees of this workshop will learn:• How to design a resume so recruiters and hiring managers can easily find the information they’re looking for and increase the chances of a callback• How to demonstrate skills and experiences for bench roles, scientific coordination roles, and scientific communication roles• How to discuss the scope and impact of experience without making information “too technical” for hiring authoritiesAttending this event and completing the reflection is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students.

event_title: University Libraries presents: Mastering Graduate Research
event_summary: Graduate research can be both an exhilarating and challenging journey, demanding a balance of rigorous scholarship and innovative thinking. In our upcoming workshop, “Mastering Graduate Research,” we will equip you with practical tips and strategies to navigate this academic odyssey. We’ll delve into effective time management techniques to juggle your research commitments and personal life seamlessly, and discuss ways to cultivate a productive mindset that fosters creativity and resilience. You’ll learn the art of crafting effective searches, mastering literature reviews, and engaging with the academic community through conferences and publications. This workshop is designed not only to enhance your research skills but also to provide a supportive environment where you can share experiences, ask questions, and build a network of peers. Whether you’re just starting out or already developing your thesis/dissertation, this session promises valuable insights and actionable advice to help you thrive in your graduate studies.Target audience:Graduating undergraduate students, new graduate students and/or early PhD students.Register HereAttending and actively participating in this event, and completing its reflection is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students.
event_category: training workshops, faculty, researcher, students

event_summary: Accountability is critical to healthy relationships and organizations. As you develop your ability to hold others accountable, you will improve trust, efficiency, engagement, and more.
event_description: Any manager who’s struggled to close a significant performance gap or anyone who has ever walked out of an annual review feeling like they’ve just been processed rather than prioritized knows there’s nothing easy about it.Performance management is about addressing behavior routinely and consistently. It’s about candidly coaching through challenges and fostering a culture of accountability for lapses in behavior. It’s about identifying goals, fast-tracking careers, and in the process, improving the bottom line.The good news is these accountability skills are replicable and learnable. We’re all just a few crucial skills away from learning how to manage people and performance daily and directly. Crucial Conversations for Accountability is an engaging classroom course rich with group discussion, real-time practice, and group support and coaching.Learning ObjectivesMaster performance discussions.Manage projects without taking over.Reach alignment when stakes are high and opinions vary.Strengthen trust and reliability.Apply multiple sources of influence.Get results and improve relationships.Register via TrainTraqby October 31st.If the registration deadline has passed or the date for this section doesn’t work for you, please visit theCourse Detailspage and click on the Upcoming Sections tab to explore other available options.
event_category: general interest, training workshops, faculty, staff, bryan-college station

event_summary: Conflict is a natural part of any workplace—but when left unmanaged, it can erode trust, reduce productivity, and damage team morale. This course, developed by HRDQ and Organizational Development, equips participants with the tools and strategies to recognize, manage, and prevent conflict in a constructive and collaborative way.
event_description: Through interactive activities, real-world scenarios, and practical tools, participants will explore the most common sources of workplace conflict, identify their personal conflict-handling style, and learn how to apply best practices for resolution and prevention. The course emphasizes self-awareness, communication, and proactive problem-solving to foster a healthier, more productive work environment.This course is designed to help participants:Identify their preferred strategy for handling conflict.Understand the characteristics and drawbacks of common conflict approaches.Recognize typical sources of workplace conflict.Apply strategies to resolve conflict based on its source.Practice behaviors that minimize tension and promote collaboration.Proactively address issues before they escalate.Register via TrainTraqby November 6th.If the registration deadline has passed or the date for this section doesn’t work for you, please visit theCourse Detailspage and click on the Upcoming Sections tab to explore other available options.

event_title: Common Grounds - Sustainability Starts at Your Desk: Everyday Actions with Impact
event_summary: The University Staff Council invites staff to join us for “Common Grounds,” a series to connect staff with University Leadership on a variety of topics.
event_description: JoinKelly Wellman,Sustainability Director, for an update on sustainability at Texas A&M.At a large university, thousands of small daily decisions—from what we print to how we commute—add up to significant environmental and social impacts. Sustainability doesn’t require major lifestyle overhauls; it begins right at your desk, in your office, lab, or vehicle. Join this session to learn about the university’s sustainability performance and discover practical, easy-to-implement actions that not only reduce your environmental footprint but also improve efficiency, support university goals, and enhance well-being in your workplace.This will be aone-hour presentation before theUSC Meeting. The series can be attended in person at theGeneral Services Complexin Room 101A orvia Zoom.Kelly Wellmanis the Sustainability Director at Texas A&M University (TAMU), where she leads key initiatives, collaborates with students, faculty, and staff to advance a comprehensive sustainability program, oversees the Aggie Green Fund, and guides implementation of the university’s Sustainability Master Plan. She holds a BS in Geography with an Environmental Studies emphasis from TAMU (1995), an MBA from the University of Phoenix (2006), and a Master of Jurisprudence in Environmental and Energy Law and Policy from TAMU School of Law (2023).
event_category: campus life, general interest, listening session, staff, bryan-college station, canyon, dallas , fort worth, galveston, houston, mcallen, round rock, temple, washington d.c.

event_summary: Experience an accelerated introduction to emotional intelligence. Understand your current level of EQ from the Emotional Intelligence Appraisal assessment results and create your own EQ Development Plan with goals and strategies to put to practice.
event_description: Whether you are aware of them or not, emotions are intertwined in everything you think, do, and say each day on the job, in your career and throughout your life. Emotional intelligence (EQ) is how you handle yourself and others on the job.Organizations that embrace EQ development within their workforce experience:Better team collaboration and improved productivityKeen resilience and effective leadershipMore engagement and increased work satisfactionImproved organizational cultureTalentSmart’s Mastering EQ® Level 1 will take participants far beyond knowing what EQ is and how they score on their first EQ assessment.Learning ObjectivesDiscover what EQ is, why it matters in all aspects of life, and how to develop it to be more effective.Increase awareness of emotions and the fundamental role they play at work and in life.Explore the four EQ skills in action: Self-Awareness, Self-Management, Social Awareness, and Relationship Management.Discuss real world examples and experience, what works and what doesn’t work, and what to do moving forward.Understand their current level of EQ (strengths and weaknesses) and where to focus their development.Complete an EQ Development Plan to include one EQ goal and specific EQ practice strategies that will help achieve that.Register via TrainTraqby November 17th.
event_category: training workshops, faculty, staff, bryan-college station

event_title: Washington-on-the-Brazos State Historic Site Reopening Celebration
event_description: Join in celebrating the grand reopening of Washington-on-the-Brazos State Historic Site, following a transformative $54 million renovation. The site, where delegates signed the Texas Declaration of Independence in 1836, has been thoughtfully updated ahead of the upcoming 190th anniversary of Texas’ independence in 2026.The renovation enhances the visitor experience with more interactive and engaging storytelling elements that bring Texas history to life. Highlights include a fully reimagined Star of the Republic Museum with immersive theaters and rareartifacts, as well as the new Washington Town Site, which features recreated historic buildings and archaeological exhibits. Attendees will also be able to enjoy an upgraded visitor center, expanded family gallery that is equipped with children’s toys from the 1830s and a full day of programming from living history interpreters.

Feel the ground shake and engines roar at the Museum of the American G.I.’s History in Motion! Watch historic tanks, military vehicles, and artillery spring to life in a thrilling, action-filled weekend that brings the past into the present. You’ll experience one of the South’s premier collections of fully restored WWII and Vietnam-era vehicles—in motion.This family-friendly event is packed with exciting activities for all ages! Tanks and vehicles will run throughout the day, with special demonstrations featuring historic weapons, artillery, and rare vehicles. Between shows, explore the displays up close—or climb aboard for a ride in a WWII tank or Half-Track!
event_category: general interest, international students

event_summary: November 15 is the final application deadline for Spring ’26 externships.
event_description: Spring ’26 Externships:The Externship Program is accepting applications from students interested in externing for the Spring ’26 term. Pre-approved opportunities can be found inREVS.The Externship Application Process:A two-step processReceive an in internship/externship offer. Students can apply to a pre-approved placement (find inREVS) or find their own opportunity.Apply for approval to enroll in the Externship course. All students must submit an application to enroll in the course throughREVS’ experiential learning module.If the attorney/organization is not pre-approved (see employer profile inREVS), there is an additional step to approve the supervisor before a student can take the course.Overall deadline to apply for the Spring ’26 Externship course isNovember 15;even if you haven’t secured an externship offer, you should submit a request by this date. Late requests may be approved on a case-by-case basis.Questions: Visit theExternship websitefor further information or contact Prof. Becker atcbecker@law.tamu.edu. You can also make an appointment via REVS’ appointment module.

event_title: TLI: The Legal Landscape of Financial Technology
event_summary: Tech Law Initiative: The Legal Landscape of Financial TechnologyNovember 19, 202512-1pmLecture Hall
event_description: What is Cryptocurrency, and how is it changing financial services? What are the biggest legal battles being fought in the fintech space right now? And what does a legal career in this cutting-edge field actually look like?Get answers to these questions and more at our lunchtime panel. Featuring Kate Vanderkolk, the in-house counsel from a local crypto-lending company and Professor Andrea Tosato, a renowned academic expert on cryptocurrency, this session is your perfect entry point into fintech law. We’ll discuss the core technology, the state vs. federal regulatory landscape, and the day-to-day life of a fintech lawyer. Bring your questions and ask the experts during the Q&A! Join Tech Law Initiative in exploring the intersection of technology, finance, and law.

event_summary: The Office of Sustainability & Campus Enrichment’s Undergraduate Internship Program applications close today. Learn more at sustainability.tamu.edu.
event_description: The goal of the Office of Sustainability & Campus Enrichment’s Internship Program is to bring undergraduate students from a variety of backgrounds and perspectives together to create a dynamic team that works to create a culture of sustainability at Texas A&M University. Interns work together to increase awareness and education about the three pillars of sustainability: environmental, economic, and social. The team focuses on educating the campus community about topics such as: energy and water use, transportation, food services, construction and built environment, purchasing, recycling, and social sustainability through the development of outreach initiatives and event coordination. Additionally, interns support assessment and planning efforts prioritized by the office.The Internship Program is open to any TAMU undergraduate student and all majors are encouraged to apply because true sustainability must be an interdisciplinary enterprise.Applications are open October 6, 2025 – November 9, 2025 at sustainability.tamu.edu.

event_description: The Office of Undergraduate Research (UGR) invites you to a relaxed, come-and-go event where students can explore how to get involved in research at Texas A&M—over coffee and cookies, of course!Hosted by our Undergraduate Research Ambassadors, the Café offers informal Q&A sessions, peer support, and networking opportunities in a casual setting. Whether you’re just starting to explore research or need help emailing faculty, finding a project, or polishing a resume, our Ambassadors are here to help.Faculty & Staff: Curious how UGR staff or Ambassadors can support your students? Stop by to learn how we can partner with you to introduce undergraduates to research.This event is open to the public, and our Ambassadors—representing a variety of majors—are excited to chat with you!

event_title: The First Galaxies and Black Holes: Surprises from JWST
event_summary: Host:Bingjie Wang (Princeton University)
event_description: The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) is transforming our understanding on galaxy formation and evolution, revealing distant galaxies deep into the epoch of reionization and red sources that were simply unknown previously. In this talk, I will present some of the most surprising discoveries of the JWST era. I will begin with one of JWST’s first deep fields, the A2744 cluster field, targeted as part of the UNCOVER survey. This rich, public dataset, reveals stellar populations across 0.2 < z < 13, and helps to lead to the discovery of some of the most distant galaxies known to date. I will then turn to a new population of compact red sources, revealed by JWST’s optical and infrared sensitivity. Initially interpreted as apparently massive galaxies at z > 7, these objects imply a strongly accelerated timeline compared to standard models of galaxy growth. Yet, major uncertainties remain about their nature. I will show detailed studies of these so-far mysterious “little red dots”, enabled by the spectroscopic data from the RUBIES program. Potential origins and evolutionary tracks will be explored, from the cores of massive galaxies to black holes embedded in a dense hydrogen cloud. I will conclude with remaining puzzles and possible future directions to form a complete physical picture of these intriguing systems.
event_category: speakers, forums, and conferences, bryan-college station

event_title: Division of Student Affairs Monthly Staff Development Program
event_summary: As Student Affairs professionals, we often interact with students during moments of challenge, transition, and crisis. These encounters position us to notice when a student may be struggling, but they can also leave us questioning the best next step.
event_description: This program will provide practical guidance on how to:Recognizebehaviors that may indicate a student is in distress or displaying concerning behaviorRespondwith strategies that balance care, professionalism, and campus policy.Referstudents to the appropriate campus resources to ensure they receive the support they need.Through expert perspectives from Student Life, University Police, University Health Services, and Residence Life, along with scenario-based activities, participants will strengthen their confidence in navigating concerning student behaviors. Together, we will reinforce our shared commitment to fostering a safe, supportive, and thriving Aggie community.

event_title: Hands-on Manufacturing of mRNA Vaccines & Therapeutics
event_summary: In this course we cover topics related to the manufacturing of mRNA vaccines in a simulated cGMP environment. Participants will perform manufacturing unit operations and quality control testing of a model mRNA vaccine. Participants that successfully complete the course will receive a Texas A&M Engineering Experiment Station Completion Certificate and 3.7 Continuing Education Units (CEU’s).
event_description: Laboratory modules will utilize bench scale unit operations to establish process parameters. Participants will then get hands-on experience with commercial scale equipment for the in vitro transcription reaction, chromatography and UF/DF unit operations.This course also provides participants with hands-on QC testing to supplement learning on drug substance and drug product critical quality attributes and release testing.
event_category: training workshops, faculty, researcher, staff, students, visitors, bryan-college station

event_title: 26th Susanne M. Glasscock Book Prize Lecture
event_summary: The Melbern G. Glasscock Center for Humanities Research at Texas A&M University has awarded theTwenty-Sixth Annual Susanne M. Glasscock Book Prizeto Eva Payne, for her bookEmpire of Purity: The History of Americans’ Global War on Prostitutionpublished by Princeton University Press in 2024. Join us for Dr. Payne’s Award Lecture & Prize Presentation.
event_description: Eva Payne is associate professor of US history at the University of Mississippi. Her research and teaching examine the 19th- and 20th-century U.S. with a focus on women, gender, and sexuality and the U.S. in transnational perspective. Her first book,Empire of Purity: The History of Americans’ Global War on Prostitution,was published by Princeton University Press in 2024 and has been featured in such publications as theNew YorkerandBBC History.The prize, first awarded in 1999, was permanently endowed in December 2000 by Melbern G. Glasscock ’59 as a gift for his wife, Susanne, for whom the prize is named. This unique prize celebrates outstanding works of original, interdisciplinary humanities scholarship that appeal to both academic and wider audiences.

event_title: MSEN Seminar: On-Demand Control of Single-Molecule Chemistry through Vibrational Characterization and Manipulation
event_summary: Dr. Shaowei LiAssistant professorUniversity of California, San Diego
event_description: Abstract:Chemical processes hinge on the dynamic rearrangement of nuclei within molecules. Controlling these motions with precision has been a long-standing goal in chemistry. My lab focuses on achieving this by manipulating interactions between individual molecules and their nanoscale environment. We engineer the potential energy surface at this scale to control molecular properties such as structure and reactivity.Using vibrational characterization techniques with scanning tunneling microscopy (STM)—including inelastic electron tunneling spectroscopy, action spectroscopy, and our recent advancement in single-molecule infrared absorption spectroscopy—we analyze molecular responses to the variation in the nano-chemical environment by examining their fingerprinting vibrational modes at the sub-molecular scale. By precisely tuning the junction geometry, material, and the interaction between the molecule and other surface entities, we can selectively influence specific bonds, paving the way for bond-selective control in chemistry.Bio:Dr. Shaowei Li is an assistant professor at the University of California, San Diego. He received B.S. in Physics and Mathematics from Nankai University in 2010 and Ph.D. in Physics from the University of California, Irvine in 2017. Before joining UC San Diego, he was a postdoc scholar at Northwestern University and later a Heising-Simons Junior Fellow at UC Berkeley. His research focuses on probing the fundamental properties of low-dimensional systems including single molecules and layered materials with scanning tunneling microscopy and spectroscopy. His group combines scanning tunneling microscopy with optical spectroscopy to explore light-matter interaction at the atomic scale.

event_title: University Libraries presents: Harnessing the Power of Research Metadata
event_summary: Description:Effective management and understanding of research metadata are crucial for ensuring your data is discoverable, understandable, and reusable. This workshop, “Harnessing the Power of Research Metadata,” will guide you through the key principles and practices for creating high-quality metadata. Participants will learn how to document descriptive, administrative, structural, and technical aspects of their data, making it easier to share and collaborate. The session will highlight the importance of metadata in meeting the FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable) principles and provide hands-on exercises to apply these concepts to your own datasets. Whether you’re managing large datasets or just starting your research journey, this workshop will equip you with the knowledge and tools to optimize your research metadata.Audience:Graduate students, research faculty/staff, and anyone doing research in general.Register HereAttending and actively participating in this event, and completing its reflection is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students.

event_title: Grammar in Instruction: Exploring the Impact of Articles (a/an/the) and Plurals on Clarity and Compr
event_description: Grammatical errors can hinder successful spoken communication. Speakers can communicate with more clarity and specificity when they correctly use articles (a, an, the) and plurals, thus avoiding confusion. In this workshop, attendees will review and practice using articles and plurals in the context of providing a clear teaching demonstration on a topic in their field of study. An optional assignment for extended practice will be available on Canvas.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to...1. Identify situations or contexts within their teaching domains where the correct usage of articles and plurals is crucial for avoiding ambiguity.2. Provide clear and unambiguous instructions, explanations, or demonstrations on topics within their field of expertise by appropriately employing articles and plural forms.

Identify alternative assessment methods suited to different learning objectives.2. Describe the benefits and challenges of non-exam assessments.3. Compare traditional and alternative assessments in terms of student learning outcomes.4. Develop an assessment plan that aligns with course goals and promotes deeper learning.

This four-session pronunciation workshop systematically explores the vocal tract and segments of speech that make meaningful differences in North American English. Through a variety of activities and handouts, attendees will become familiar with each consonant sound and with resources to practice listening discrimination and accurate pronunciation on their own. They each have the opportunity to get personalized feedback on their own pronunciation.

event_title: Academy for Future Faculty - Understanding Institutional Structure
event_description: The AFF Executive Committee will discuss navigating institutional differences in higher education. Participants will examine how various types of institutions—such as research universities, teaching-focused colleges, and community colleges—may emphasize different qualifications, skills, and experiences in faculty roles. The session will provide insights to help graduate students better understand institutional priorities and prepare for diverse career opportunities in academia.Participants will be able to:1. Compare the priorities of different types of higher education institutions.2. Analyze how institutional structures influence faculty roles and responsibilities.3. Prepare to tailor application materials and professional goals to institutional expectations."

event_title: NACADA Webinar: Learning How to Learn: Preparing Students to be More Effective Learners
event_description: While academic advisors are fiercely committed to promoting academic success for all students, many have never received instruction in evidence-based learning strategies. Attendees will learn about empirically supported strategies that they can utilize to promote students' academic success. Attendees will also learn how about the various ways in which academic advisors have woven the Three Ms into distinct components of student success advising. event_title: Brains Behind the Chatbots: How Transformers Power Large Language Models
event_description: Chatbots like ChatGPT may seem magical, but what’s really going on inside their “brains”? The answer is Transformers—a breakthrough in artificial intelligence. Unlike older models that read words one at a time, transformers look at an entire sentence (or even a whole paragraph) at once, figuring out how each word relates to the others. This “attention” trick allows large language models (LLMs) to generate smooth, meaningful text, translate languages, and even hold conversations that feel natural. In this talk, we’ll break down the magic behind transformers using simple examples, explore how models learn from huge amounts of data, and play with the “settings” that shape their personality—like temperature (how creative the AI sounds) and top-k (how many word options it considers). By the end, you’ll understand not only how these models work, but also why they’re changing the way we study, work, and create.

event_title: NACADA Webinar: Supporting Students Through a Trauma-Informed Lens
event_description: More students are arriving on campus with experiences of trauma that shape how they learn, engage, and seek support. Academic advisors are often among the first professionals to build trust. This webinar will introduce foundational principles of trauma-informed advising, equipping you with practical strategies to recognize signs of trauma, respond with empathy, and help students connect to resources if needed. Presenters Kaiti Blackburn (Jana's Campaign) and Shantalea Johns (Wayne State University) will draw on research and their lived experiences to discuss how trauma can impact a student's brain, behavior, motivation, and academic performance. You'll learn how to create safer advising spaces, support students through challenges, and make intentional choices that foster dignity and belonging, without overstepping your role or taking on more than is sustainable.

event_title: NACADA Webinar: Small Changes, Big Impact: Creating Institutional Structure to Support New Advisor D
event_description: The process of training as a new advisor can often be a trial by fire. Advising offices can create practices and resources that give structure and support to the learning process for new advisors, and NACADA’s Core Competencies and New Advisor Development Chart provide a map of what should be learned. Yet the process of creating comprehensive training and development programs from the ground up can feel daunting (if not impossible). This webinar’s hosts will share their experiences creating structures to support new advisor learning and break down their developments into manageable steps for implementation. We will help you dream big in design and think small in implementation to see your interventions compound changes over time (and will include a few helpful resources to get started with those small changes).

event_title: [UGR] Undergraduate Research Scholars Writing Abstracts Workshop
event_description: Want to publish your research? A great abstract is not only a requirement for the Undergraduate Research Scholars program, but it is also serves as the “resume” for your research to outside viewers and prospective publishers. Because writing an abstract is an unfamiliar process for those who are new to research, we want to teach you the basics. Visit https://uwc.tamu.edu for more information and help on writing abstracts.

event_title: [UGR] Undergraduate Research Scholars Presentation Skills Workshop
event_description: At this workshop, you will learn the DOs and DON’Ts of giving a presentation. We will give you tips about the best way to present a poster, as well as instruct you on how to effectively use a PowerPoint presentation. Because a public presentation of your research is a requirement of the URS thesis program, we highly recommend this workshop as a helpful resource. Visit https://uwc.tamu.edu for more information on giving effective presentations. Visit https://tx.ag/URSthesis to learn more about the Undergraduate Research Scholars thesis program.

event_title: NACADA Webinar: Please Won't You Be My Advisor?
event_description: Fred Rogers, writer, producer, and actor for the infamous public television show Mr. Roger's Neighborhood, believed that the kindness and support of 'just one person' could help a child to reach their full potential. As advisors, most of us entered this helping profession with exactly that in mind-the hope that we can cheerlead alongside our students to help them to build the pathways and successes to support their greatest goals. In this episode, listeners will 'ride along through the neighborhood' and learn about Fred Rogers' theory of personal development and its applications to academic advising. We will examine the 'just one person' model and its potential influences for specialized and underrecognized populations of students, including refugee students. Second, we will apply Mr. Roger's four 'simple interactions approach,' which includes the basic interaction strategies of creating connection, inclusion, reciprocity, and opportunity for growth. Finally, we will explore how adviso

event_title: NACADA Webinar: Reset for College Success: From Suspension to Graduation
event_description: Is your institution looking for a fresh, new way to support probation and reinstated students? At our institution, we have created a course designed to empower students by developing skill sets geared toward academic, personal and professional success. This presentation is led by two knowledgeable instructors who have a combined 8 semesters of course instruction. Topics featured are course design, weekly course topics, assignments, how we provide support throughout the semester and data to back up our findings over the 5 years of the Suspension Waiver Program.

Interested in writing an undergraduate thesis? Undergraduate Research staff will explain the details, opportunities, and eligibility requirements for the Undergraduate Research Scholars thesis program. As long as you are an undergraduate, this program is open to all majors. Faculty research advisors are encouraged to attend with undergraduates. More information about the program can be found at https://tx.ag/URSthesis Published Undergraduate Theses can be found in our OAKTrust Collection at https://oaktrust.library.tamu.edu/handle/1969.1/3367.

Artificial Intelligence is rapidly reshaping the landscape of higher education, from how students access information to how institutions provide support. But what does this mean for academic advisors? In this timely and practical session, Jeff Elliott (Purdue University) and Mitch Colver (American Public University System) will explore how AI tools can be integrated into advising workflows in meaningful, ethical ways. The session will address real-world use cases, such as drafting outreach messages, organizing notes, and managing repetitive tasks, while also tackling key questions around data privacy, professional judgment, and student trust. Whether you're cautiously curious or actively experimenting with AI, this conversation will help you move forward with confidence.
